a Manner to all Intents and Purposes as he, she, or they could or might have held and enjoyed the same in case this Act had not been passed; and that the said Lords, Ladies, and Owners of the Manors within which the said Townships or Divisions are situated for the Time being, shall and may from Time to Time, and at all Times hereafter, have, hold, work, and enjoy all Mines, Minerals, and Quarries, of what Nature or Kind soever, within or under the said Commons and Waste Grounds intended to be divided and inclosed as aforesaid, as well those not opened as those already opened (save and except the said public Quarry to be set out as aforesaid, and sufficient Stones and Quarries of Stone in the several Allotments aforesaid for the Use of the respective Proprietors), and to have and enjoy and be vested with all convenient and necessary Ways,

Heap Rooms, Drifts, Levels, Watercourses, erecting and using Fire Engines and other Engines, and all and every other Matters and Things now in use or hereafter to be invented for the Purposes aforesaid, or any of them, in, through, upon, over, or along the said Commons and Waste Grounds, or any of them, or any Part or Parts thereof, and all other Powers, Privileges, and Authorities for all or any Part of the Purposes aforesaid, in the same Manner as if this Act had not been passed.

LI. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the several Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty duly authorized to print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a Copy thereof so printed by any of them shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges, Justices, and others.

An Act for settling and securing Parts and Portions of the Lands and Barony of Irwermay, in the County of Perth, to and in favour of Alexander Hepburn Belshes Esquire, and the Series of Heirs entitled to take by certain Deeds of Entail made by Barbara Hepburn and others, and Sir Patrick Hepburn Murray, and under the Conditions and Limitations contained therein; and for vesting in lieu thereof the Barony and Estate of Blackcastle in the Counties of Haddington and Berwick, in the said Alexander Hepburn Belshes, and his Heirs and Assigns, in Fee Simple.

but by reason of the Limitations and Conditions contained in the said Deeds of Entail, these Ends cannot be attained without the Aid and Authority of Parliament : May it therefore please Your Majesty, upon the humble Petition of the said Alexander Hepburn Belshes and Major John Belshes, the only Heirs of Entail of the said Estates in Life, that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this Act, the said Alexander Hepburn Belshes, at any Time during his Life, or failing him, the Heir of Entail for the Time being, or his or her Tutors or Curators, if under the Age of Twenty-one Years, who shall be seised of and in possession of the said entailed Estate of Blackcastle, and others aforesaid, comprised in the said recited Deeds of Entail, and set forth in the First Schedule annexed to this Act, shall and may be at liberty to apply by summary Petition to the Court of Session in Scotland, in either of its Divisions, and by and with the Direction and Approbation of the said Court, to make,

II. And be it further enacted, That after the said Disposition or Deed of Settlement and Entail shall be so made and executed in Manner and to the Effect aforesaid, the same shall be recorded in due Form in the Register of Taillies, for the Benefit and Security of all and every Person and Persons interested therein, and a Charter or Charters may and shall pass and be obtained thereupon, and Infeftment or Infeftments taken by virtue of the Precept or Precepts therein contained, and recorded agreeably to the Forms of the Law of Scotland; upon all which the said Court shall interpone its Authority, by declaring that the Directions by this Act given have been complied with, according to the true Intent and Meaning thereof.

III. And be it enacted, That from and immediately after the granting and executing of the foresaid Disposition and Deed of Settlement and Entail, recording of the same, passing the Charter or Charters thereupon, and the taking and recording the Infeftment or Infeftments as before mentioned, and the Authority of the Court of Session being interponed thereto, the said Lands and Estate of Blackcastle, contained in the said First Schedule hereunto annexed, shall be and the same are hereby settled and vested in the said Alexander Hepburn Belshes and his Heirs and Assigns in Fee Simple, and the same shall from thenceforth be freed, and absolutely acquitted, released, exonerated, and discharged of and from all the Conditions, Provisions, Declarations, Limitations, Prohibitions, and Irritancies contained in and imposed by the said Deeds of Entail, and shall from thenceforth be at the free and absolute Disposal of the said Alexander Hepburn Belshes, and his Heirs and Assigns.

IV. Saving always, and reserving to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, to any Legatees or Annuitants that are or may be existing and unpaid, and heritable Creditors upon the said Estate, and to all and every other Person or Persons, Bodies Politic and Corporate, his, her, or their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, and Successors, (other than and except the said Alexander Hepburn Belshes, and the Heirs of Entail entitled to succeed to the said Barony and Estate of Blackcastle and others, by virtue of the said Deeds of Entail before recited), all such

5 Estates,

Cap A 1.

An Act for effecting an Exchange between the Provost and Scholars of the King's College of Blessed Mary and Saint Nicholas of,

and the Master or Keeper, Fellows and Scholars of the College or Hall commonly called Clare Hall, in the University of Cambridge.

[30th May 1823.]

WHEREAS the Provost and Scholars of the King's College of Blessed Mary and Saint Nicholas of Cambridge are seised, to them and their Successors for ever, of a Parcel of Ground situate in the Town of Cambridge in the County of Cambridge called Butt Close, for many Years past, and now in the Occupation of the Master or Keeper, Fellows and Scholars of the College or Hall commonly called Clare Hall in the University of Cambridge, as Tenants to the said Provost and Scholars, containing Two Acres Two Roods and Thirty-four Perches, bounded on the North by Gerrard’s Hostle Lane, on the East by the River Camf and on the South and West by other Grounds belonging to the said Provost and Scholars, with the Buildings and Trees now standing and being thereon, and the Rights and Appurtenances thereto belonging r And whereas the said Master or Keeper, Fellows and Scholars are seised, to them and their Successors for ever, of a small Parcel of Ground in Cambridge aforesaid, with the Appurtenances, whereupon Part of the ancient Building or Foundation of Clare Hall aforesaid did formerly stand, [Private.'] % % as

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 12.

An Act to amend and enlarge the Powers and Provisions of an Act of His late Majesty King George the Third, for inclosing and improving Beam Heath, in the Township of Alvaston, in the Parish of Nantwich, in the County Palatine of Chester.

[30th May 1823.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Forty-third Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act for inclosing and improving a certain Tract of Common or Waste Land called Beam Heath, in the Township of Alvaston, in the Parish of Nantwich, in the County Palatine of Chester: And whereas the Trustees appointed under or by virtue of the said Act have proceeded in the Execution of the Powers and Authorities vested in them by such Act; and a considerable Portion of the said Common or Waste Land hath been inclosed and improved, and great Benefit hath thereby accrued to the Persons having Interest therein or Rights thereupon: And whereas the Powers and Provisions of the said Act have been found defective and insufficient for the Purposes thereby intended, and it is expedient that the said Act should be repealed, and that more efficient Powers should be granted instead thereof, and further and more effectual Provision made for the Regulation of the Use and Occupation of the Lands composing the said Heath, and for the Application of the Money arising from such Lands; but the several beneficial Purposes aforesaid cannot be effected without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please : [Private3 Your

4° GEORGII IV. 12.

Your Majesty that it may be enacted $ and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this Act, the said recited Act shall be and the same is declared to be repealed, and that this Act shall thenceforth take effect and be put in force for inclosing and improving the said Common or Waste Land called Beam Heath, and for otherwise carrying this Act into Execution.

II. And be it further enacted, That James Bayley, John Barker, Thomas Bebbington the younger, William Betteley, George Cappur, Washington Cliffe, James Cooper, Thomas Cope sticky John Downes, Thomas Deriemer, John Eardley, William Garnett Clerk, John Jasper Garnett, Edward Kent, John Latham Clerk, John Latham, Richard Leversage, John Minshull, William Massey, Charles Mare, James Parratt, James Plevin, John Pratchett, Benjamin Rodenhurst, Joseph Skerrett, William Sprout, Thomas Steele, Crowdson Tunstall, William Tomlinson the elder, Henry Tomlinson, Daniel Tomlinson, and John Withenshaw, shall be and they are hereby appointed Trustees for executing this Act.

III. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That no Person herein named as a Trustee, or who shall hereafter be elected a Trustee on Vacancy, as hereafter mentioned, shall be capable of acting as such Trustee until he shall have taken and subscribed, before One or more of the said Trustees, an Oath or Affirmation in the Words or to the Effect following; that is to say,

I A.B. do swear [or, being a Quaker, do affirm], That I am an Inha-

* bitant Householder of the Town of Nantwich, entitled to the Benefit ‘ of the Inclosure of Beam Heath; that I am worth the Sum of Five

* hundred Pounds in Real or Personal Property, after Payment of all my

* just Debts; and that I am not, directly or indirectly, a Tenant, Lessee,

* or Occupier of any of the said inclosed Lands; and I further swear 4 [or affirm, as the Case may be\, that I will faithfully, impartially, and 4 honestly, according to the best of my Skill and Judgment, execute and

* perform the several Trusts and Duties reposed in me by virtue of an Act, intituled [here set forth the Title of this Acf\, according to Equity 4 and good Conscience, and without Partiality, Favour, or Affection, 4 Prejudice or Malice, to any Person whomsoever. So help me GOD.*

[Or, being a Quaker, omit the Words ‘ So help me God.’]

Which said Oath or Affirmation the said Trustees, or any One or more of them, are and is hereby empowered to administer.

IV. And be it further enacted, That when and so often as any Vacancy shall occur amongst the said Trustees, either by the Death of any Trustee or by his Desire to be discharged from acting as such Trustee, or by his becoming incapable of acting, or by his absenting himself from Six successive Meetings (whether General or Special), without assigning sufficient Cause to the Majority of the Trustees present at their next Meeting, or by knowingly or wilfully committing any Act or Acts, either directly or indirectly, contrary to the Provisions in this Act contained, which shall be decided upon by the Majority of the Trustees aforesaid; or in case of any such Trustee ceasing to be qualified in manner by this Act directed,

VI. And be it further enacted, That all Acts, Orders, and Proceedings Meetings and of the Trustees acting in Execution of this Act, shall be done, made, and Quorum of had by the major Part of the Trustees present at their several Meetings, Tl'ustees* the whole Number present not being less than Three (except in Cases where any other Number is herein named), and all Acts, Orders, and Proceedings had, made, or done by or before such Three Trustees, shall have the same Force and Effect, and shall be binding and conclusive on all Persons, and to all Intents and Purposes whatever, as fully and effectually as if the same were had, made, or done by or before all the said Trustees; and at every Meeting to be held by virtue of this Act, a Chairman shall and may in the first Instance be appointed, who in case of an equal Number of Votes upon any Occasion, including such Chairman’s Vote, shall have thecasting or decisive Vote : Provided always, that Two Trustees shall be sufficient for the Purpose of Adjournment only; and in case a competent Number of Trustees shall not appear at the Time and Place appointed, at any Meeting of the Trustees, either to act or to adjourn, or in case the Trustees at any Time assembled shall omit or neglect to adjourn themselves, then and in either of such Cases it shall be lawful for any Two or more of the said Trustees (or for the Clerk to the said Trustees, being authorized by an Order in Writing signed by any Two or more of the said Trustees), to call a Meeting of the said Trustees, by Notice to be affixed to the Door of the Parish Church of Nantwich,

VII. And be it further enacted, That if after any Adjournment of the said Trustees, it shall at any Time be thought necessary that an earlier Day of Meeting should be appointed than the Day appointed by such Adjournment, it shall be lawful for any Three or more of the said Trustees, or for the Clerk to the said Trustees, by an Order in Writing, signed by any Three or more of the said Trustees, although not assembled at a Meeting, to give Notice in manner herein-before directed of such earlier Meeting, and in such Notice shall be expressed the Time, Place, and Purpose of such earlier Meeting, such Time being not less than Three Days after such Notice; and such earlier Meeting shall and may be held accordingly; and all the Orders and Determinations of the said Trustees at all such Meetings, shall be as valid and effectual as they would have been in case such Meetings had been held in pursuance of Adjournments.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That such of the said Trustees as are or shall be Justices of the Peace, may within their respective Jurisdictions act as Justices of the Peace in the Execution of the said recited Act and this Act, notwithstanding their being Trustees, except only in Cases wherein they shall be personally interested.

IX. And be it further enacted, That all Notices required to be given by this Act, shall (in Cases where the Manner of giving such Notices is not herein otherwise mentioned) be given by affixing the same to the principal outer Door of the Church of the Parish of Nantwich aforesaid.

X. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees may, by Writing under their Hands, elect and appoint a Clerk or Clerks, and Treasurer or Treasurers, Receiver or Receivers, Collector or Collectors of such Money as shall arise and be made due and payable by virtue of this Act, and all such other Officers as they the said Trustees shall think necessary and proper to be employed in the Execution of the Powers of this Act, and also may remove from Time to Time all such Clerks, Treasurers, Collectors, Receivers and other Officers, or any of them, as they the said Trustees shall see occasion; and upon the Death, Resignation, or Removal of such Officers, or any or either of them, the said Trustees may appoint others in their stead; and the said Trustees shall and may, out of the Money to be raised and received by virtue of this Act, make such Allowance

ance unto the Clerks, Treasurers, Receivers, Collectors, and all other Officers so appointed, and to such other Persons as shall be assisting in the Execution of this Act, as to them the said Trustees shall seem proper; and the said Trustees are hereby empowered to take Bonds with sufficient Sureties from every such Treasurer, Clerk, Officer, or Person, for the due and faithful Execution of his Office; and every Officer and Person Officers to who shall be so appointed as aforesaid, shall from Time to Time, when account, thereunto required by the said Trustees by Writing under their Hands, make out and deliver to such Trustees, or to such Person or Persons as they shall for that Purpose appoint, a true and perfect Account in Writing under his Hand, of all Monies which shall have been by him had, collected, or received, and how and to whom and for what Purpose the same and every Part thereof hath or have been disposed of, together with the Vouchers and Receipts for such Payments; and every such Officer or Person shall and is hereby required to pay all such Monies as upon the Balance of such Account shall appear to be owing from him to such Person or Persons as the said Trustees shall appoint to receive the samej and if any such Officer or Person shall refuse or neglect to render and Proceedings deliver up such Account as aforesaid, or to produce and deliver up the Vouchers and Receipts relating to the same, or to pay the Balance thereof fusing*^6" when thereunto required, in Manner aforesaid, or shall refuse or neglect account, &c. to deliver up to the said Trustees, or to such Person or Persons as they shall appoint, within Seven Days after being thereunto required by the said Trustees, or by such other Person or Persons, all Books, Papers, and Writings in his Custody or Power, relating to the Execution of this Act, then and in every such Case, Complaint being made thereof by the said Trustees, or by any Person on Behalf of the said Trustees, of any such Neglect or Refusal, to any Justice of the Peace for the County Palatine of Chester, such Justice may and he is hereby authorized and required, by Warrant under his Hand and Seal, to cause such Officer or Person to be brought before him, and upon his appearing or not being to be found, to hear and determine the Matter of such Complaint in a summary Way, and to settle the said Account, if produced, in such Manner as the said Trustees might have done; XI. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful for the said Trustees to appoint the Person who may be appointed to act as their Clerk in the Execution of this Act, or the Partner of any such Clerk, or the Clerk of or any Person in the Service or Employ of any such Clerk, the Treasurer for the Purposes of this Act, or to appoint the Person who may be appointed Treasurer, or the Partner of any such Treasurer, the Clerk to the said Trustees for executing this Act; and if any Person shall act in both the Capacities of Clerk and Treasurer for the Purposes of this Act, or if any Person, being the Partner of any such Clerk, or being the Clerk of or any Person in the Service or Employ of any such Clerk, shall act as Treasurer, or being the Partner of any such Treasurer, shall act as Clerk in the Execution of this Act, or if any Treasurer shall hold any Place of Profit or Trust under this Act, other than that of Treasurer, every such Person so offending shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay the Sum of Fifty Pounds to any Person or Persons who shall sue for the same, to be recovered in any of His Majesty's Courts at Westminster, by Action of Debt or on the Case, or by Bill, Suit, or Information, wherein no Essoign, Protection, or Wager of Law, or more than one Imparlance shall be allowed.

XII. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall cause proper Books to be provided and kept, and regular Entries to be made therein, as well of all their Orders and Proceedings relative to the Execution of this Act, as of the Names of all such Trustees as shall be present at their several Meetings; and all Entries in such Books, signed by the Chairman then present, shall be allowed to be read in Evidence in all Suits, Actions, and Proceedings touching or concerning any thing done or to be done in pursuance of this Act; and such Books shall at all Meetings of the said Trustees be open to the Inspection of all or any of the said Trustees; and all or any of the said Trustees shall be permitted to have Copies thereof, or of any of the Entries therein, paying for such Copies after the Rate of Sixpence for every Seventy-two Words.

XIII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That none of the Trustees of this Act shall be answerable or accountable for the other or others of them, or for involuntary Losses; and that by and out of any Money which shall come to their or his Hand or Hands by virtue of any

9 of

195

4° GEORGII IV. CapA%

of the Trusts created by this Act, it shall be lawful for them and him to retain and reimburse themselves and himself respectively, all the necessary Costs, Charges, and Expences which they or he may respectively incur or sustain in carrying the Trusts of this Act into Execution, and not herein provided for.

XIV. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall yearly appoint, by Writing under their Hands, Four fit Persons to appear at the Court Leet and Court Baron of the Lord of the Manor and Barony of Nantmch, and out of such Four Persons Two Persons shall be appointed and sworn by the Steward of the said Court, as Heath Keepers, and such Heath Keepers shall, under the Direction and subject to the Controul of the said Trustees, do every thing appertaining to the said Office; and it shall be lawful for the said Trustees to allow to the said Heath Keepers such Salaries as they the said Trustees shall deem reasonable; and the said Trustees shall and may cause the said Heath Keepers to be removed, and others to be appointed in their stead, as occasion may require.

XV. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall and they are hereby empowered to set out and appoint and cause to be made and completed such public Bridleways and Footways in, over, upon, and by the Sides of the Heath or Common by this Act directed to be inclosed and improved, as they shall think requisite, and the same Bridleways and Footways respectively shall be made, and at all Times thereafter repaired and maintained by the said Trustees, by and out of the Monies to arise under or by virtue of this Act.

XVI. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall and they are hereby authorized and empowered, if they shall judge necessary and proper, to divert, turn, or stop up, alter, change, widen, or enlarge any of the Roads, Ways, or Footpaths, passing or leading through or over any of the Lands or Grounds composing the said Heath called Beam Heath: Provided always,that no such Road, Way, or Path shall be diverted, turned, or stopped up, or discontinued, without the Concurrence and Order of Two of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace, acting in and for the Division in which such Road, Way, or Path lies, and not interested in the Repair thereof; which Order shall be subject to Appeal at the Quarter Sessions, in like Manner and under the same Forms and Restrictions as if the said Order had been made by such Justices, and also subject to the Rules, Orders, and Directions mentioned and contained in an Act passed in the Fifty-fifth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act to amend an Act of the Thirteenth Tear of His present Majesty, for the Amendment and Preservation of the public Highways, so far as the same relates to Notice of Appeal against turning or diverting a public Highway, and to extend the Provisions of the same Act to the stopping up of unnecessary Roads.

XVII. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees to cause such Buildings, not exceeding Two Cottages, to be erected on such Part or Parts of the said Common or Waste Land, as they shall think fit, and to let the same at such Rents as they shall judge reasonable.

XVIII. And be it further enacted, That the said Common or Waste Land, called Beam Heath, as well that which is already inclosed by virtue of the said former Act as that which is hereby directed to be inclosed and improved, shall from and after the passing of this Act be vested in the Trustees for the Time being, appointed or to be appointed under the Authority hereof, in Trust for the Intents and Purposes herein-after mentioned; and the said Trustees for the Time being shall for evermore stand seised of the said Heath hereby directed to be inclosed and improved, upon the several Trusts herein-after mentioned and declared; (that is to say), there being Eighty-nine Statute Acres of the said Common or Waste Land remaining uninclosed, it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, and they are hereby authorized and empowered, to inclose, drain, fence, ditch, and cleanse the Whole or any Part of such Common or Waste Land; and the same when inclosed shall (if the said Trustees shall so think proper) be marled, and undergo a regular Course of Tillage, in the same Manner as the Land inclosed under the said former Act hereby repealed; or the same, when inclosed, shall undergo such other Course of Improvement as the said Trustees in their Discretion shall think proper; and it shall be lawful for the said Trustees from Time to Time to cause such Repairs and Improvements to be done and made to such Heath, by ditching, draining, fencing, and otherwise, as the said Trustees shall think proper.

XIX. And be it further enacted, That all Persons being entitled to and having enjoyed the Benefit of Leys upon the said Heath under or by virtue of the Powers and Provisions of the said former Act hereby repealed, and being now entitled thereto, shall continue to enjoy the same under or by virtue of this Act, whilst they remain qualified as in this Act is directed.

XX. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for all the Inhabitant Householders of the said Township of Nantwich, who were resident there as such before Lady-day One thousand eight hundred and two, and all other Inhabitant Householders of the said Township, after they shall have been resident therein as such for the Space of Seven successive Years, or if born or having served a Seven Years Apprenticeship in the same Township, and the Widows of any such Persons dying after having been so resident, to have the Benefit of Leys for all their Cattle (except Asses, uncut Horses of Two Years old or upwards, and Pigs), on such Part or Parts of the said Heath as shall be set apart by the said Trustees for that Purpose, paying to the said Trustees, previously to turning on such Cattle, such Sum, not exceeding Five Pounds, as the said Trustees may think proper: Provided always, that no Person or Persons who shall hereafter come to reside in the said Township of Nantwich , being a Pauper or Paupers of and belonging to any other Township or Townships, shall be entitled to the Benefit of the said Leys, or any Share of the Surplus Monies hereafter mentioned, by means of any such Residence as Householders in Nantwich.

XXI. And be it further enacted, T.hat the said Trustees shall yearly make out a Schedule of the several Prices or Rates which are intended to be charged for the then ensuing Year, for Leys upon the said Heath, which Schedule shall be made known to Persons entitled to Leys in the Month

of

4° GEORGII IV. Cap. 12.

of January in each Year 5 and no Person shall turn into the Ley more than Two Horses, or more than Three Two-year-old Colts, or Four One-year-old Colts, or Three Cows, or Four Two-year-old Heifers, or Five Stirks, or Twenty Sheep, and such Cattle shall be charged equally per Head, according to the Description of Cattle turned on; (that is to say), if the Rate of the Leys be Three Pounds per Annum, the First Horse shall be charged One Pound and Ten Shillings, and the Second Horse One Pound Ten Shillings; or if Twenty Sheep be turned into the said Heath, Three Shillings per Head shall be charged for each Sheep so turned into the said Heath.

XXII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if any Person shall have become entitled to Leys on the said Heath, and shall afterwards leave the Town of Nantwich aforesaid, such Person shall, after returning to Nantwich, be a resident Householder therein for Two successive Years before he shall be entitled to Leys upon the said Heath.

XXIII. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, after having appointed so much and such Parts of the said Heath as shall appear to them necessary for Leys, to lease the Remainder or Part of such Heath, in such Parts and for such agricultural Purposes as they may think expedient; and the said Trustees shall and may at some public Meeting of the said Trustees, to be held for that Purpose (of which Meeting and the Purpose thereof Notice shall be given at least Fourteen Days previous to such Meeting), let the remaining Parts of the same Heath, or so much thereof, either together or in Parcels, as they may think proper, by public Auction, to the highest Bidder for such Letting, from Year to Year, or for any Term of Years, not exceeding Fourteen Years from the Commencement of such Letting; so that the Rent or Rents for the same, to be reserved upon every Lease of or Agreement for taking the Premises, or any Part thereof, shall be thereby reserved to be paid to the said Trustees or their Treasurer by Four equal quarterly Payments in every Year; and so that there be also reserved and made payable to the said Trustees, or their Treasurer, the best and most improved Rent or Rents that can be reasonably had or gotten for the same, without taking any Fine, Premium, Sum of Money, or Foregift, or any thing in the Nature of a Fine, Premium, or Foregift, or other Consideration for such Letting; and so that the Tenant or Lessee be not made dispunishable for Waste, and so that there be inserted in every such Agreement or Lease a Power of Re-entry on Nonpayment of the Rent or Rents to be thereby reserved within a reasonable Time to be therein limited after the same shall become due; and so as such Agreement or Lease shall contain all proper Penalties, Provisions, Covenants, Regulations, and Restrictions for securing the due Payment of the said Rent, and for the Occupation, Cultivation, and Management of the Premises therein comprized, and in all other respects whatsoever, according to the best and most improved System of Husbandry practised in the Neighbourhood thereof; and so that a Counterpart or Duplicate of each such Agreement or Lease be duly executed by the Tenant or Tenants, Lessee or Lessees, with or to whom such Agreement or Lease shall be made as aforesaid; and every such Agreement or Lease shall be valid and effectual in Law, to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever; any thing in this Act, or in any Law or Usage to the contrary notwithstanding.

XXIV. Provided always, and be it further enacted, lhat none of the said Trustees, or any Officer or other Person acting under the Authority of this Act, shall directly or indirectly become or be admitted as Tenants of any Land on the said Heath, save and except Persons having Garden Land attached to their Cottages, and which Garden Land shall not exceed Eight Roods of Eight Yards Square to each Rood of Land to each Cottage.

XXV. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall set out and allot so much of the said Common or Waste Land as they shall think proper, for procuring Gravel, Sand, or other Materials to be used for the Repair of the Roads on such Common, or for the Repair of any other Road within any Part of the Township of Nantwich, and also for getting Sand for any agricultural or other Purpose on such Heath, as the said Trustees shall think proper.

XXVI. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, by and out of the Monies to arise by virtue of this Act, yearly to lay out and expend any Sum not exceeding Fifty Pounds in the Purchase of Dung, Compost, and Manure, or other Matter or Materials for the Improvement of the said Ley Lands, and may cause the same to be laid and spread upon such Part or Parts of the Land only as they may think proper and direct.

XXVII. And be it further enacted, That the Time of opening the said Leys shall be from the Twelfth to the Twentieth of May fat the Discretion of the Trustees), for Horned Cattle, Horses, and Colts, and the Time of concluding such Leys shall be from the Twelfth to the Twentieth Day of October; and for Sheep, from the Twelfth or Twentieth Day of May to the Fourth of December; but it shall be lawful for any Person or Persons taking the Benefit of such Leys as aforesaid, to remove any of the Cattle by him, her, or them turned upon the said Common or Waste Land, and to turn upon the same (on giving Notice to the Heath Keepers for the Time being of his, her, or their Intention so to do), a Number of such Cattle as may be so removed, at any Time or Times during the Season.

XXVIII. And whereas gross and innumerable Frauds have been committed by Persons fraudulently turning Cattle on the Leys, in the Names of Persons entitled to Leys upon the said Heath; for future Prevention whereof, be it further enacted, That all Parties being entitled to and claiming the Benefit of Leys shall, at the Time of their entering or causing to be entered in the Ley Book to be kept by the said Heath Keepers (and which Book the said Heath Keepers are hereby directed to provide) any Cattle or other Stock as belonging to him, her, or them, shall sign a Declaration that the Stock or Stocks so turned on by him, her, or them, is or are his, her, or their Property; and in case any Person shall turn any Cattle or other Stock, as belonging to him, her, or them, on the said Ley, not being his, her, or their Property, every Person so offending shall for the First Offence be totally deprived of and from any Benefit arising from the said Leys, Common or Waste Lands, or from the Proceeds arising therefrom, in any respect whatsoever, for and during the Term of Three Years; and for the Second Offence such Person shall be

4°GEORGII IV. Cap.lt

be wholly excluded from any Benefit whatsoever arising from the said Leys, Common or Waste Lands; and it any Person not entitled to the Benefit of the said Leys, Common or Waste Lands, shall fraudulently tarn any Cattle or other Stock, as the Property of him, her, or them, as qualified Persons, such Person shall for every such Offence forfeit such Cattle to the said Trustees, who are hereby authorized to sell the same by Public Auction; and the Proceeds arising from such Sale, after defraying the Expences thereof, shall be apportioned by the said Trustees in manner following, that is to say, One Half to the Informer, and the other Half to the general Funds arising from the said Waste Lands to be applied to the general Purposes of this Act; and in case any Person, whose Privilege as a Householder or Householders shall be accruing due, shall fraudulently turn any Cattle or other Stock on the said Leys in the Name of any qualified Person, such Cattle or other Stock so turned on shall be forfeited to the Trustees, and disposed of in the Manner aforesaid; and such Person shall for the First Offence be deprived of any Benefit of the said Waste Lands for the Term of Three Years, which shall be computed from the Period at which his Privilege would have commenced; and for the Second Offence the Cattle shall be forfeited in like manner, and the Person or Persons so turning on shall be excluded any Benefit whatsoever arising from the said Waste Lands; and it any Person being so entitled shall turn on Cattle in the Name of any other qualified Person such Person shall forfeit his or her Cattle to the said Trustees, who shall dispose of the same in the Manner herein-before directed; and such Person shall also for the First Offence be totally deprived of any Benefit or Advantage arising from the said Waste Lands for the said Term of Three Years; and for the Second Offence the Cattle shall be forfeited, and the Proceeds disposed of in manner aforesaid, and the Person so turning on such Cattle shall be excluded from all Benefit and Advantage whatsoever arising from the said Waste Lands.

XXIX. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall and they are hereby authorized and required to hold a Meeting, within Three Days after the first turning Cattle on the said Heath, and at any Time subsequently, as they may think proper, for the Purpose of examining the List of Names and Stock turned on, in order that if Suspicion attach to any Person or Persons, the said Trustees may summon such Parties to appear before them at their next Meeting, giving them Seven Days Notice thereof, for the Purpose of examining such Parties so suspected of having illegally turned Cattle on the Heath, on Oath or Affirmation as to the Truth of the before-mentioned Declaration, which Oath or Affirmation the said Trustees, or any of them, are or is hereby authorized to administer; and any Person having received Notice as aforesaid, and refusing to attend such Meeting, without assigning a satisfactory Cause to the Trustees for their Non-attendance, or attending and refusing to be sworn or to give Evidence, shall to all Intents and Purposes be considered guilty of the said Offence, and shall be subject to the Penalties and Forfeitures herein-before mentioned: Provided always, that every Person shall be competent to give Evidence for any Offences committed against this Act, notwithstanding he or she may be an Inhabitant Householder or Inhabitant Householders of the said Township of Nantwich, and entitled to Leys under or by virtue of this Act.

XXX. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, if they shall judge it expedient so to do, to appropriate Part of the said Common or Waste Land for the Purpose of making Bricks, or carrying away Sand or Gravel; and every Person making Bricks or carrying away Sand and Gravel, by Permission of such Trustees, shall pay to the said Trustees for such Privilege such Sum or Sums of Money as shall be determined on by the said Trustees, and agreed to by such Person, and such Sum and Sums of Money shall be applied to the general Fund raised for the Purposes of this Act.

XXXI. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall have full Liberty and Power to make Bricks or Tiles on the said Heath, to be used for the Purpose only of erecting, forming, and keeping in repair such Buildings as the said Trustees, under the Provisions of this Act, are empowered to erect, or are now erected, and any Culverts, Bridges, and Drains, or for other agricultural Purposes, as from Time to Time may be requisite on the said Heath, or any Part thereof.

XXXII. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall cause a certain Part of the said Common or Waste Land to be appropriated yearly to the Growth of Potatoes, for the Benefit of such of the said Householders as shall require the same, and to such as the said Trustees shall in their Discretion think proper to grant the same; and the Quantity of Land to be allowed yearly to each Householder for such Purpose shall be determined by the said Trustees; and the Person or Persons who shall take the Benefit of such Appropriation, shall pay to the said Trustees such Sum, not exceeding Three-pence per Rood, reckoning Eight Yards Square to the Rood, as the said Trustees shall determine.

XXXIII. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees to cause such Number of Trees to be planted annually in the Hedge Rows of the Fields or Closes into which the said Common or Waste Land shall be divided, and also upon or near to the Banks of any River or Rivulet, and for the Purpose of affording Shade for Cattle in such other Part or Parts thereof as they shall think fit, and to cause such Trees when of sufficient Growth (provided the same be not wanted for Shade for Cattle) to be cut down and sold; and the Money arising by the Sale thereof shall be applied to the Purposes of this Act.

XXXIV. And be it further enacted, That any Surplus of Monies which shall from Time to Time come into the Hands of the said Trustees by virtue of this Act, shall immediately thereupon be placed into the Hands of the Treasurer or Treasurers as aforesaid (in the Name of the said Trustees), who shall allow the usual Bank Interest for the same; and the Treasurer or Treasurers in whose Hands the said Money shall be so placed, shall give Security and Satisfaction to the said Trustees for all such Monies as shall be placed in his or their Hands; and such Treasurer or Treasurers shall not pay or apply any Part of such Money for any Purpose whatsoever, without an Order from the Trustees for that Purpose; and when and so often as the Surplus of the Income arising by virtue of this Act shall amount to the Sum of Five hundred Pounds, and not before, (after Payment of all Expences, Debts, and Salaries already incurred, and which the said Trustees may incur by carrying this Act into Execution,

201

4° GEORGII IV. Cap.n.

tion, and otherwise,) the same shall with all convenient Dispatch be distributed by the said Trustees amongst such Inhabitant Householders of Nantwich, as under or by virtue of this Act shall be entitled to the Benefit of Leys, in equal Shares, Share and Share alike.

XXXV. And be it further enacted, That all the Costs, Charges, and Expences incident to and attending the obtaining and passing of this Act, shall be defrayed by the said Trustees, in preference to all other Payments and Disbursements whatsoever, by and out of any Monies already in the Hands of the said Trustees, or by and out of the first Monies which shall come to their Hands by virtue of this Act.

XXXVI. And be it further enacted, That a General Meeting of the said Trustees shall be holden annually in the Month of June, for the Purpose of examining the Accounts of the Treasurer and all other Officers and Persons employed in the Execution of this Act; and it shall be lawful for the said Trustees to allow and pass such Accounts as may appear to them correct; and such Trustees shall cause Copies of such Accounts so allowed to be distributed amongst the Inhabitants of Nantwich entitled to Leys, within One Month after the passing of such Accounts.

XXXVII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That the ancient inclosed Lands in the Township of Alvaston shall be totally exempted from all Statute Duty and Composition, but the Beast Gates within the same (which Beast Gates shall be confined to such Part or Parts of the said Heath as shall from Time to Time be in Pasture, but not upon any other Part or Parts thereof, and subject in every respect to the same Restriction in Pasturage as the Cattle turned on by Persons entitled to Leys on the Heath) shall pay their Proportion annually to all Assessments; and the said Trustees shall have full Power to purchase or rent all or any of the Beast Gates from the Proprietors thereof, if they shall be willing to sell or let the same, if the said Trustees shall think proper so to do.

XXXVIII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That the said Common or Waste Land shall not be charged with any Assessment whatsoever, affecting the ancient inclosed Lands or any other real Property lying within the Township of Alvaston, previously to the passing of this Act; and every Person who shall or may after the passing of this Act gain a Settlement on the said Heath, shall be relieved solely from the Proceeds of the said Heath, and from the Proceeds of any Rate or Assessment which may be made affecting the said Beast Gates.

XXXIX. And be it further enacted, That if any Person shall hereafter erect, set up, or build any Cottage, Hut, or other Building on any Part of the said Heath (whether the Party or Parties so erecting or causing the same to be erected shall be in the Occupation thereof or not,) without Permission of the said Trustees, it shall be lawful for the said Trustees or their Agents, Workmen, or Servants, by their Directions, forthwith to pull down or cause the same to be pulled down, without any other Authority than this Act.

XL. And be it further enacted, That all Penalties, Forfeitures, and Fines by the said recited Acts or this Act inflicted or authorized to be imposed (the Manner of levying, recovering, and applying whereof is not herein otherwise directed), shall, upon Proof of the Offences respectively before any Justice of the Peace for the County Palatine of Chester, either by the Confession of the Party offending, or by the Oath of any credible Witness or Witnesses (which Oath such Justice is in every such Case hereby fully authorized to administer), be levied, together with the Costs attending the Information and Conviction, by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Party or Parties offending, by Warrant under the Hand and Seal of such Justice (which Warrant such Justice is hereby empowered and required to grant); and the Overplus, if any, after such Penalties, Forfeitures, and Fines, and the Charges of such Distress and Sale, are deducted, shall be returned upon Demand unto the Owner or Owners of such Goods and Chattels; and in case such Fines, Penalties, and Forfeitures shall not be forthwith paid upon Conviction, then it shall be lawful for such Justice to order the Offender or Offenders so convicted to be detained and kept in safe Custody until Return can be conveniently made to such Warrant of Distress, unless the Offender or Offenders shall give sufficient Security, to the Satisfaction of such Justice, for his or their Appearance before such Justice on such Day or Days as shall be appointed for the Return of such Warrant of Distress, such Day or Days not being more than Seven Days from the Time of taking any such Security, and which Security the said Justice is hereby empowered to take by way of Recognizance or otherwise; but if upon the Return of such Warrant, it shall appear that no sufficient Distress can be had thereupon, then it shall be lawful for any Justice of the Peace as aforesaid, and he is hereby authorized and required, by Warrant or Warrants under his Hand and Seal, to cause such Offender or Offenders to be committed to the Common Gaol or House of Correction of the County or Place where the Offender shall be or reside, there to remain without Bail or Mainprize for any Time not exceeding Three Calendar Months, unless such Penalties, Forfeitures, and Fines, and all reasonable Charges attending the same, shall be sooner paid and satisfied; and the Monies arising by such Penalties, Forfeitures, and Fines respectively, when paid or levied, if not otherwise directed to be applied by the said recited Acts, shall be from Time to Time paid to the Treasurer to the said Trustees, and be applied and disposed of for the Purposes of the said recited Acts and this Act.

XLI. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons Allowing shall think himself, herself, or themselves aggrieved by any Thing done Appeal, in pursuance of this Act, then and in every such Case, he, she, or they may appeal to the General or Quarter Sessions of the Peace to be holden in and for the said County of Chester, within Six Calendar Months next after the Cause of Complaint shall have arisen, giving Fourteen Days Notice of such Appeal and of the Matter thereof, in Writing to the said Trustees; and the Justices at their General or Quarter Sessions (not being interested in the Matter in question) are hereby authorized and required to hear and determine the same, and to make such Order therein, and award such Damages and Costs as to them in their Discretion shall seem reasonable, and by their Order or Warrant to levy such Damages and Costs by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Party or Parties directed to pay the same, rendering the Overplus (if any) upon Demand, to the Owner or Owners of such Goods and Chattels, after deducting the reasonable Charges of every such Distress and Sale; which Determination of the said Justices shall be final and conclusive upon all Parties concerned, and shall not be removed or removeable by any Writ,

Wherefore Your Majesty's loyal and dutiful Subjects, the said Richard Buck and Margaret his Wife, on behalf of themselves and of the said Robert Buck, Catherine Dauntesey Buck, Margaret Buck, and John Buck, their Infant Children, and also the said 1 homas Hull, do most humbly beseech Your Majesty that it may be enacted \ and be it enacted by the King’s

V. And be it further enacted, That all Monies which pursuant to the Direction herein-before contained shall be paid into the Bank of England as aforesaid, or so much thereof as shall not be ordered by the said Court of Chancery to be from Time to Time paid to the said Richard Buck and Margaret his Wife, or the Survivor of them, or the Persons so claiming in Remainder under the said recited Will, or any Appointment to be made in pursuance thereof as aforesaid, or to be applied in Payment of the Costs, Charges, and Expences according to the Provisions herein contained, shall in the meantime, and until the same Monies shall be invested in the Purchase of Manors, Messuages, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, be from Time to Time laid out by the Accountant General of the said Court of Chancery in the Purchase of Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills, and the Interest arising from the Money so laid out in the said Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills, and the Monies received for the same as they shall respectively be paid off by Government, shall from Time to Time be laid out in the Name of the said Accountant General in the Purchase of other Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills; provided that it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court to make such General Order or Orders, or Special Order or Orders if necessary, that whenever the Exchequer Bills of the Date of those in the Hands of the Accountant General shall be in the Course of Payment by Government, and new Exchequer Bills shall be issued, such new Exchequer Bills may be received in Exchange for those which are so in the Course of Payment as shall be effectual for enabling such Receipt in Exchange, and that in that Event the Interest of the old Bills shall be laid out as before directed with respect to the Interest where the Bills are paid off; all which Navy, Victualling, and Exchequer Bills shall be deposited in the Bank of England in the Name of the said Accountant General, and shall there remain until the same shall, upon Petition to be preferred to the said Court of Chancery in a summary Way as aforesaid, be ordered to be sold by the said Accountant General for completing any such Purchase or Purchases as aforesaid; and if the Money arising by the Sale of such Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills shall exceed the Amount of the original Purchase Money so laid out as aforesaid, then and in that Case only the Surplus which shall remain after discharging the Expences of the Application to the Court, shall be paid to such Person or Persons respectively as would have been entitled to receive the Rents and Profits of the Lands directed to be purchased, in case the same had been purchased pursuant to this Act, or to the Representative or Representatives of such Person or Persons respectively.

VI. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Court of Chancery, upon Petition to be preferred in a summary Way as aforesaid, from Time to Time to make such Orders as the said Court shall think expedient, just, or reasonable, for allowing, taxing, and settling all Costs, Charges, and Expences which have been or shall be incurred in obtaining and passing this Act, and making the several Applications to the Court in pursuance hereof, and in making or completing the Demise or Demises of the Mines and Hereditaments hereby made demisable, and in surveying and measuring the said Mines and Hereditaments, and ascertaining from Time to Time the Quantities and Amounts of Coals, Cannel, and other Minerals, to be dug or gotten by virtue of such Demise or Demises, and in paying into the Bank of England as aforesaid such Rent or Rents as is or are herein-before directed to be so paid, and in investing all or any Monies which under this Act shall be paid into the Bank of England, in the Purchase of Estates, according to the Directions herein contained, or otherwise in carrying the Trusts and Purposes of this Act into Execution, and also from Time to Time to make such Orders as the said Court shall think expedient for Payment of all such Costs, Charges, and Expences aforesaid, out of the Monies so to be paid into the Bank, or out of the Monies arising by Sale of the Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills so to be purchased as aforesaid.

VII. And be it further enacted, That upon a Petition to be presented in a summary Way as aforesaid, all the Costs, Charges, and Expences preparatory to and attending the applying for and obtaining and passing this Act, and incidental thereto, together with Interest on such Monies as may have been or shall be advanced or subscribed by any Person or Persons for or towards raising and providing the same Costs, Charges, and Expences, and all the Costs, Charges, and Expences attending or relating to the Demise or Demises hereby authorized, and all the Costs, Charges, and Expences of surveying and measuring the said Mines and Hereditaments, and of ascertaining from Time to Time the Quantities and Amounts of Coals, Cannel, and other Minerals to be dug or gotten by virtue of such Demise or Demises, or of or relating to the several Applications to be made to the said Court respecting the Matters aforesaid, and the Costs incurred in taking the said Monies out of the Bank, and investing the same in such Manors, Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, and in investigating the Title of the same, or otherwise in carrying any of the Trusts and Purposes of this Act into Execution, shall be paid and satisfied out of the Monies which shall be so paid into the Bank as aforesaid, or out of the Monies arising by Sale of the Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills so to be purchased as aforesaid, such Costs, Charges, and Expences being first taxed and ascertained by one of the Masters of the said Court, in pursuance of an Order or Orders which the said Court is hereby authorized to make.

VIII. Saving always to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, and to all and every other Person and Persons, Bodies Politic and Corporate, his, her, or their Heirs and Successors, Executors and Administrators, (other than and except the said Richard Buck and Margaret his Wife, and the Survivor of them, and all the Children of the said Margaret now born and hereafter to be born, and their respective Heirs and Assigns, and the Heirs, Appointees, or Assigns of the said

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 14.

An Act for exchanging an Estate in the County of Wilts, whereof John Biddulph Esquire and Augusta his Wife, and Philip Jones Esquire and Sarah his Wife, have joint Power of Disposition, for Estates in the Counties of Warwick and Worcester, settled by the Will of Sarah Richards, in Trust for the same Parties and their Children.

[17th June 1823.]

WHEREAS Sarah otherwise Sally Richards, late of the City of Bath, in and by her last Will and Testament in Writing, duly executed and attested as by Law is required for passing Real Estates, bearing Date the First Day of March in the Year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and eleven, did, amongst other things, give and devise all her Freehold, Copyhold, and Leasehold Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, with the Appurtenances, situate, lying, and being in the several Counties of Warwick, Worcester, and Wilts, or elsewhere, the Copyhold Part whereof she had surrendered to the Use of her Will, unto John Biddulph of Champion Hill in the County of Surry, Esquire, and Philip Jones of Sugwas near Hereford in the County of Hereford, Esquire, and David Gordon the elder, of Denmark Hill in the said County of Surryf Gentleman, and their Heirs, Executors, and Administrators, according to the Nature of the several Estates, to the Uses, upon the Trusts, and for the Intents and Purposes therein-after expressed concerning the same, (that is to say) as, to, for, and concerning One Moiety or Half Part of all her said Freehold, Copyhold, and Leasehold - [Private.'] 3 { ' Estates,

all that Capital Messuage or Dwelling House, and other the Tenements or Cottages, and the several Pieces or Parcels of Arable, Meadow, Pasture, and Wood Land held or occupied therewith, in the said Deed Poll mentioned to contain together, by Estimation, Three hundred and fifty-five Acres more or less, but which in fact contain, by Admeasurement, Four hundred and eleven Acres or thereabouts, situate in the several Parishes or Places of Sherstone Pinckney and Sherstone Magna in the County of Wilts, (which said Premises are more particularly described in the Second Schedule to this Act annexed), are and stand limited and conveyed to the Uses herein-after expressed, (that is to say), as to one undivided Moiety or equal Half Part or Share of and in the said Messuages or Tenements, Farms, Lands, Hereditaments, and Premises, and of and in their Appurtenances, to such Uses, upon such Trusts, and to and for such Intents and Purposes, and with, under, and subject to such Powers, Provisoes, Agreements, and Declarations, as the said John Biddulph the elder and Augusta his Wife shall during their joint Lives by any Deed or Deeds, Writing or Writings, with or without Power of Revocation and new Appointment, to be by them sealed and delivered in Presence of and attested by Two or more credible Witnesses, from Time to Time direct, limit, or appoint; and the said John Biddulph the elder and Augusta his Wife, Ann Penelope Biddulph, Robert Biddulph, Philip Jones the elder, and Sarah, otherwise Sally, his Wife, are severally desirous that the said Estates comprised in the said Second Schedule, whereof they the said John Biddulph and Augusta his Wife, and Philip Jones, and Sarah, otherwise Sally, his Wife, have jointly such absolute Power of Disposition and Appointment as aforesaid, should, discharged of the Uses and Limitations limited or declared thereof in and by the said herein-before recited Deed Poll and Fine, be vested in and settled upon the said John Biddulph the elder, Philip Jones the elder, and David Gordon the elder, their Heirs and Assigns, as Trustees under the said recited Will, to the Uses, upon the Trusts, and for the Intents and Purposes in and by the said Will expressed and declared concerning the Estates thereby devised, and that thereupon the said devised Estates should be freed and discharged from the Uses, Trusts, and Limitations expressed and contained in the said Will, and should be substituted, limited, and settled to the Uses and in Manner in and by the said recited Deed Poll and Fine expressed and declared of and concerning the said Hereditaments and Premises therein comprised; but although such Substitution and Exchange of the said. Estates as above proposed, would be advantageous to all the said several Parties beneficially interested therein respectively, yet by reason of the Limitations contained in the Will of the said Sarah otherwise Sally Richards, such Substitution and Exchange cannot be carried into Effect without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: Wherefore Your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal Subjects, the said John Biddulph the elder, and Augusta his Wife, on Behalf of themselves and their said Eight Infant Children; and the said Ann Penelope Biddulph and Robert Biddulph; and also the said Philip Jones the elder, and Sarah otherwise Sally his Wife, on Behalf of themselves and their said Four Infant Children, do most humbly beseech Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That from and immediately after the passing of this Act, the Messuages or Tenements, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments, mentioned and described in the First Schedule to this Act annexed, together with all and every the Rights, Members, and Appurtenances thereto belonging, and the Reversion and Reversions, Remainder and Remainders, Rents, Issues, and Profits of the same Premises, shall be, and the same are hereby absolutely freed and discharged of and from the Uses, Trusts, and Limitations expressed or declared of and concerning the same in and by the said Will of the said Sarah otherwise Sally Richards, and so freed and discharged shall (in Exchange and Substitution for the Messuages or 1 enements, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments

223

4° GEORGII IV.

mentioned and described in the said Second Schedule to this Act annexed), go, remain, and be limited, settled, and assured to the Uses, upon the Trusts, and for the Intents and Purposes, and with, under, and subject to the Powers, Provisoes, Limitations, and Declarations in and by the said recited Deed Poll or Instrument in Writing of the Eighteenth Day of March One thousand eight hundred and twenty-three limited, expressed, declared, and contained of and concerning the Messuages, Lands, and Hereditaments comprised in the Second Schedule to this Act annexed, or to, upon, for, with, under, and subject to such of the same Uses, Trusts, Intents, Purposes, Powers, Provisoes, and Declarations, as immediately before the passing of this Act were subsisting or capable of taking Effect.

II. And be it further enacted, That from and immediately after the passing of this Act the Messuages or Tenements, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments, particularly mentioned and described in the said Second Schedule to this Act annexed, with their Rights, Members, and Appurtenances, and the Reversion and Reversions, Remainder and Remainders, Rents, Issues, and Profits of the same Premises, shall be, and the same are. hereby accordingly absolutely freed and discharged of and from the Uses, Trusts, Powers, and Limitations in and by the said recited Deed Poll or Instrument in Writing of the Eighteenth Day of March One thousand eight hundred and twenty-three, and the Fine thereby referred to, or either of them, limited, created, expressed, declared, or contained of and concerning the same, and so freed and discharged shall (in Substitution and Exchange for the said Messuages, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments, comprised in the said First Schedule to this Act annexed) be vested in the said John Biddulph the elder, Philip Jones the elder, and David Gordon, their Heirs and Assigns, to the Uses, upon the Trusts, and for the Intents and Purposes, and with, under, and subject to the Powers, Provisoes, and Declarations, in and by the said Will of the said Sarah otherwise Sally Richards limited, expressed, declared, and contained of and concerning the Messuages, Lands, Tenements, Hereditaments, and Premises in the Counties of Warwick and Worcester, by the same Will devised, or such of the same Trusts, Intents, and Purposes, Powers, Provisoes, and Declarations as are now subsisting or capable of taking Effect.

III. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons legally or equitably claiming under any of the Devises or Limitations contained in the said Will of the said Sarah otherwise Sally Richards, shall at any Time or Times hereafter, without his, her, their, or any of their wilful Neglect or Default, be lawfully evicted or turned out of the Possession of the said Messuages or Tenements, Farms, Lands and Hereditaments, mentioned and described in the Second Schedule to this Act annexed, by any Person or Persons legally or equitably having or claiming, or hereafter to have or claim any Estate, Right, Title, or Interest, in, to, or out of the same, so as to be in anywise prevented or hindered from holding and enjoying the same Hereditaments and every Part thereof, according to the Intent and Meaning of this Act, then and in such Case the said Messuages, Farms, Lands, Hereditaments, and Premises mentioned in the First Schedule to this Act annexed, shall immediately thereupon go and revert to the Uses, upon the Trusts, and

IV. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That in case any Person or Persons, who under or by virtue of the Uses, Trusts, or Limitations, expressed and contained, declared or created in and by the said recited Deed Poll or Instrument, and Fine therein referred to, or either of them, shall be entitled to any Estate, Right, Title, or Interest, of, in, to, or out of the Messuages or Tenements, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments, described in the First Schedule to this Act annexed, shall at any Time or Times hereafter, without their, his, or her wilful Default, be lawfully evicted or turned out of Possession of the same Messuages or Tenements, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments, by any Person or Persons legally or equitably having or claiming, or hereafter to have or claim any Estate, Right, Title, or Interest, of, in, to, or out of the same, so as to be in anywise prevented or hindered from holding or enjoying the said last-mentioned Premises, according to the true Intent and Meaning of this Act, then and in such Case the said Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, comprised in the said Second Schedule to this Act annexed, shall immediately thereupon go and revert to the Uses and Trusts, and with, under, and subject to the Powers and Declarations, in and by the said recited Deed Poll and Fine limited, expressed, declared, or created of and concerning the same, or such of the same Trusts, Powers, and Declarations as shall be then capable of taking Effect; and then and in such Case it shall be lawful for the Person or Persons claiming or entitled as aforesaid, under the Limitations of the said Deed Poll and Fine, into and upon the said Messuages, Farms, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, comprised in the said Second Schedule to this Act annexed, to enter, and to have, hold, and enjoy the same, and to have, receive, and take the Rents, Issues, and Profits thereof, to and for his, her, or their own proper Use and Benefit, in such and the same Manner to all Intents and Purposes as he, she, or they could or might have done if this Act had not been passed, any thing herein-before contained to the contrary thereof notwithstanding.

Cap. 15.

An Act for effectuating an Exchange of an Estate in the Parish of Stone, in the County of Stafford,

(to which Ann Unett, an Infant, is entitled in Tail) for an Estate of greater Value, belonging to John Wilkes Unett and Elizabeth his Wife, and Lettice Unett.

[17th June 1823.]

WHEREAS William Unett, formerly of Groundslow Fields in the Will of Township of Tittensor, in the Parish of Stone, but then of Stone ^Villiam in the County of Stafford, Gentleman, in and by his last Will and Testament in Writing, bearing Date the Twenty-sixth Day of Septem- Tembe/^SO. ber One thousand seven hundred and eighty, executed and attested in such Manner as is by Law required for rendering valid Devises of Real Estates, gave and devised unto his Nephew William Unett, eldest Son of his then late Brother Thomas Unett deceased, ail that his Messuage or Tenement, with the Appurtenances, situate at Groundslow Fields aforesaid, commonly called or known by the Name of Oldhouse, then late in the Possession of the said Testator William Unett, but then of James Powner, with all Outhouses, Barns, Stables, Gardens, Orchards, Yards, and Backsides to the same belonging, together with the several Closes or Parcels of Land lying and being within the said Township of Tittensor, therein and herein-after particularly mentioned and described; (that is to say), the Croft below the House, and the new Meadow adjoining to it; the Close at the Backside $ the Barn, and the Close above it called the Clover Leasow; the Meadow above the House, which was formerly divided into [Private.] 3 m Two

4° GEORGII IV. CapAh.

Two Parts; the Heath Fields otherwise called the Martin's Heath Fields, into Four Parts divided, abutting to a Place called Cumber son*s Hill; the Two Upper Groundslow Fields called Martin’s Groundslow Fields, abutting also to the said Cumber son Hill; the Martin s Little Field; George Unett’s Little Field, adjoining to the said Martin’s Field; the Hill Half Acre into Two Parts divided; a Meadow adjoining the River Trent called Flax Land; and a Flat or Parcel of Land in the said Hill Half Acre, subject to and chargeable with the Payment of Twenty Shillings a Year to the Poor of the Township of Tittensor, and Ten Shillings a Year to the Poor of the Township of Sheen, on every Saint Thomas’s Day; all which said Lands were then late in the Tenure or Occupation of Richard Oram, but then of William Powner, his Assigns or Under Tenants, and all Appurtenances to the said Closes or Parcels of Land belonging or appertaining j and all Tythes and Tenths of Corn, Grain, Lamb, and Wool, yearly or otherwise coming, growing, renewing, arising, or happening from the above-mentioned Messuage or Tenement, Lands and Premises, or any Part thereof, and also from a certain Farm or Tenement in Tittensor aforesaid, called Eldershaw’s Tenement, then late in the holding of John Unett, deceased, but then of Edward Kendrick; to hold the said Messuage or Tenement, Land, Tythes, Tenths, Hereditaments, and Premises, unto his Nephew William Unett and his Assigns, for and during the Term of his natural Life, without Impeachment of Waste; and from and immediately after the Forfeiture or other Determination of that Estate, then he gave and devised the said Messuage or Tenements, Lands and Premises, to William Alsager of Trentham in the said County of Stafford, Yeoman, and his Heirs, for and during the natural Life of the said William Unett, in Trust to support and preserve the contingent Uses and Estates thereinafter limited from being defeated or destroyed, and for that Purpose to make Entries or bring Actions as Occasion should require; yet nevertheless to permit and suffer the said William Unett, or his Assigns, to take and receive the Rents, Issues, and Profits of the said Premises during his natural Life to his and their own Use and Benefit; and from and immediately after the Decease of the said William Unett, he gave and devised the said Messuage, Lands, Tythes, Tenths, and Premises, to James Robinson of Stone aforesaid, Grocer, his Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, for the Term of One hundred Years, upon the Trusts after mentioned; and subject thereto, he gave and devised the said Messuage or Tenement, Lands, Tythes, Hereditaments, and Premises, to the First Son of the Body of the said William Unett lawfully begotten or to be begotten, and the Heirs of the Body of such Son lawfully issuing; and for Default of such Issue, then to the Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, and all and every other the Son and Sons of the Body of the said William Unett lawfully begotten or to be begotten, severally, successively, and in remainder one after another, as they and every of them should be in Seniority of Age and Priority of Birth, and of the several and respective Heirs of the Body and Bodies of all and every such Son or Sons lawfully issuing, the elder of such Sons and the Heirs of his Body issuing being always preferred and to take before the younger of such Son and Sons, and the Heirs of his and their Body and Bodies issuing; and for Default of such Issue, to all and every the Daughter and Daughters of the Body of the said William Unett, lawfully begotten or to be begotten, to be equally divided amongst them, Share and Share alike, as Tenants in Common and not as Joint Tenants, and of the several and respective Heirs of the Body and Bodies of

change as aforesaid, shall at any Time or Times hereafter be lawfully recovered from or taken out of Possession of the Person or Persons in or upon whom, or to whose Use the said Hereditaments are by this Act respectively vested or settled as aforesaid, or his or their respective Heirs or Assigns, by any Right or Title precedent to the passing of this Act, without the Neglect or Default of such Person or Persons, then and from thenceforth it shall and may be lawful to and for all and every the Person and Persons, his or their Heirs and Assigns, out of whose Possession such Hereditaments shall be lawfully recovered and taken away (from and immediately after such his or their Eviction from or Loss of Possession of the sa^d Hereditaments respectively, or any Part thereof as aforesaid), to enter into the several Hereditaments hereby settled and assured, in lieu of and in exchange for the said Hereditaments which shall be so lawfully recovered and taken away, and the same to have, hold, repossess, and enjoy, as in his, her, or their first and former Estate; any thing herein-before contained to the contrary thereof in anywise notwithstanding.

IV. Saving always to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, and to all and every other Person and Persons, Bodies Politic and Corporate, his, her, or their Heirs, Successors, Executors, and Administrators respectively (other than and except the said Ann Unett, and the Heirs of her Body lawfully issuing, and the said John Wilkes Unett and Elizabeth his Wife, and Lettice Unett, and the Heirs and Assigns of them, or any of them), all such Estate, Right, Title, Interest, Claim, and Demand, of, in, to, and out of the Messuages- or Tenements, Lands, Tythes, Tenths, Hereditaments, and Premises respectively limited, settled, and assured in or by way of exchange as aforesaid, as they or any of them had before the passing of this Act, or could or might have had, held, or enjoyed, in case this Act had not been made.

V. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the several Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, duly authorized to print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a Copy thereof so printed by any of them shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges, Justices, and others.

Exchange by the said George White Thomas, Inigo Thomas, and George Thomas Thomas as aforesaid, form a very important Appendage to the said Lands so taken by them in Exchange as aforesaid, and greatly add to the Value thereof, and of the other Estates held therewith : And whereas the Income arising from the Estates of the said Sir William Lewis George Thomas, in or near Madehurst aforesaid, is very inadequate to the Expence of keeping in proper Repair and Condition the Mansion House of Dale, and the Offices, Pleasure Grounds and Park attached thereto, and of supporting an Establishment suitable to the Size and Circumstances of the said Mansion, and the only other Property of the said Sir William Lewis George Thomas, of any Value, consists of some Plantations and Estates in the Island of Antigua, which yield a fluctuating and precarious Income, and could not at present be sold to Advantage: And whereas the said Sir William Lewis George Thomas, in order to provide for the Payment of Lands, Tithes, and other Hereditaments, hereby limited and settled as aforesaid), all such Estate, Right, Title, Interest, Claim, and Demand whatsoever, of, in, to, or out of the several Messuages, Lands, Tithes, and other Hereditaments, so hereby limited and settled as aforesaid, or any of them, or any Part or Parts thereof respectively, as they or any of them had before the passing of this Act, or could or might have had, held, enjoyed, or been entitled to, in case this Act had not been passed.

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 17-

An Act for effecting an Exchange between the Right Honourable Henry Hall Viscount Gage, and the Dean and Chapter of the Cathedral Church of the Holy Trinity of Chichester, of Estates in the County of Sussex.

[17th June 1823.]

WHEREAS by Indenture of Lease, with Livery of Seisin indorsed, bearing Date the Twentieth Day of February last past, and made between the Dean and Chapter of the Cathedral Church of the Holy Trinity of Chichester, of the one Part, and the Right Honourable Henry Hall Viscount Gage, of the other Part, the said Dean and Chapter, as well in consideration that all former Leases granted by the Dean and Chapter of the Cathedral Church aforesaid, of the Parsonage Lands, Tenements, Tithes, and Hereditaments therein-after described and intended to be thereby demised, had been in due Form of Law surrendered up to the said now Dean and Chapter, and for other Considerations therein expressed, did demise unto the said Viscount Gage all that the Parsonage of Firle otherwise West Firle in the County of Sussex, with all and singular the Tenements, Gardens, Gaterooms, Barns, and other Edifices, Glebe Lands, Meadows, Pastures, Feedings, Tithes, Tenths, Oblations, Obventions, Emoluments, Rents, Casualties, Profits, Commodities, and Advantages, with the Appurtenances whatsoever to the said Parsonage belonging, and more particularly mentioned in the Terrier or Survey thereunder written; except and always reserved out of the said Demise and Grant unto the said Dean and Chapter and their Successors, all Lands, Tenements, Tithes, Rents, Profits, Commodities, and Appurtenances whatsoever. Parcel of or belonging to the Parsonage aforesaid, which were not particularly mentioned in the said Terrier or Survey; and also except and reserved the Advowson and Presentation to the Vicarage of the Church of Firle otherwise West Firle aforesaid, when and so often as the same should be void; to hold the same with the Appurtenances [Private.] 3 u o (except

Lease for Three Lives of the Parsonage of Firle, dated 20th Feb. 1823, recited.
