(except as therein-before is excepted) unto the said Viscount Gage, his Heirs and Assigns, for and during the natural Lives of John Tilson of fPat-lington Park in the County of Oxford, Esquire, of Mary Chowne Marsh, Wife of the Reverend Marsh, then or late of Busledon

in the County of Berks, and of him the said Viscount Gage, and for and during the natural Lives and Life of the longest Livers and Liver of them, at and under the yearly Rent of Thirty-one Pounds Twelve Shillings and Four-pence, payable unto the said Dean and Chapter and their Successors, and subject to the Covenants and Agreements in the said Indenture of Lease contained, and on the Part of the said Viscount Gage, his Heirs and Assigns, to be kept and performed: And whereas by Indenture of Lease, bearing Date the said Twentieth Day of February last, and made between the said Dean and Chapter of the one Part, and the said Viscount Gage of the other Part, the said Dean and Chapter, in consideration that all former Leases granted by the Dean and Chapter of the Cathedral Church aforesaid, of the Lands therein-after described and intended to be thereby demised, had been surrendered up to the said then Dean and Chapter, and for other the Considerations therein expressed, did demise unto the said Viscount Gage all those their (the said Dean and Chapter’s) Eleven Acres and One Rood of Arable and Pasture Land; whereof Seven Acres and the Rood of Land, Parcel of the said Eleven Acres and One Rood, being also Parcel of the Glebe Lands belonging to the Parsonage of West Firle in the County of Sussex, did lie and are within the Parish of West Firle, in One Furlong there, called Smede Furlong; and Five Acres of the said Seven Acres did lie together and did bound upon a Parcel of Ground of Nine Acres, formerly belonging to Sir John Gage, on the South Part, and upon Two Acres, formerly the said Sir John Gage's Land, on the North Part, and abutted upon the Drove Way there on the West Part; and One Acre and the said Rood of Land did lie in the same Furlong to the Lands sometime past of John Mascol on the South Part, and the Lands formerly of the said Sir John 1 Gage on the North Part, and abutted upon the Drove Way aforesaid on the West; and One other Close or Parcel of the said Seven Acres did lie between the Lands formerly of the said Sir John Gage on the South Part, and the King’s Highway there leading East and West on the North Part; and Four Acres of Pasture Land, Residue of the said Eleven Acres, did lie and were together at Exceit in the said County of Sussex, within a Close or Field there called Allcombe, abutting upon a Parcel of Land of Eight Acres, called Pevorells, formerly belonging to Sir Thomas West Knight, Lord De la Warr, on the North Part, and to the South Down on the West Part and on the South Part, and to Chalk Bridge on the East Part; to hold the same unto the said Viscount Gage, his Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, from the First Day of August then and now last past, for and during the Term of Twenty-one Years thenceforth next ensuing, under the yearly Rent of Eleven Shillings and Three-pence, payable unto the said Dean and Chapter, and their Successors, and subject to the Covenants and Agreements in the same Indenture of Lease contained, and on the Part of the said William Hall Viscount Gage, his Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, to be kept and performed: And whereas the said Henry Hall Viscount Gage is seised in Fee Simple in possession, free from Incumbrances, of the Farm or Farms of Frifton and Crowlink, situate in the Parish of Frifton in the County of Sussex, and of the Farm of Exceate otherwise Exceit, situate in the Parish or Hamlet of Exceit in the same County: And whereas the said Parsonage, Glebe Lands, Tithes, and other Hereditaments, demised by the said first recited Indenture of Lease, and / 6 " - also

also the Lands demised by the said secondly recited Indenture of Lease* with the Exception of the said Piece of Pasture Land at Excek aforesaid, in the same Lease mentioned to contain Four Acres, (but which by recent Admeasurement is found to contain Four Acres and Three Roods, and is known by the Name of Wainhouse Field), lie contiguous to the Capital Messuage or Mansion House of Firle, and other Estates of the said Henry Hall Viscount Gage, at or near West Firle, and are much more convenient to beheld therewith than the said Farms of Frifton, Crowlink, and Exceate otherwise Exceit: And whereas the said Henry Hall Viscount Gage and the said Dean and Chapter are desirous that the said Parsonage, Glebe Lands* Tithes, and other Hereditaments demised by the said first recited Indenture of Lease, and of which the said Dean and Chapter are seised for an Estate of Inheritance in Fee Simple, subject to the same Lease, (and which Parsonage Lands, Tithes, and Hereditaments are particularly described in the First Part of the First Schedule to this Act), should be exchanged for the said Farms of Frifton and Crowlink, and also for the said Farm of Exceate otherwise Exceit; with the Exception of a Piece or Parcel of Land containing Four Acres or thereabouts, being now or late Part of the Cow Down belonging to the said last mentioned Farm, and of another Piece or Parcel of Land containing Two Acres or thereabouts, being Part of a Piece or Parcel of Land called The Hog Brook, also belonging to the said last mentioned Farm; which Three several Farms (with the Exception of the said Two Pieces or Parcels of Land containing respectively Four Acres and Two Acres), are particularly described in the First Part of the Second Schedule to this Act; and that the Lands demised by the said secondly recited Indenture of Lease, and of which the said Dean and Chapter are also seised for an Estate of Inheritance in Fee Simple, subject to the same Lease, with the Exception of the said Piece of Land situate at Exceit aforesaid, and mentioned in the same Lease to contain Four Acres, (which Lands so demised by the said last mentioned Lease, with the Exception last aforesaid, are particularly described in the Second Part of the First Schedule to this Act, and which Piece of Land, so excepted as last aforesaid, it is proposed should continue the Estate of the said Dean and Chapter, subject to the said last mentioned Lease), should be exchanged for the said Two Pieces of Land containing together Six Acres, and being respectively Parts of the Exceit Cow Down and of the said Piece of Land called Hog Brook, and which are near to and are convenient to be held with the said Piece of Land stated in the said last mentioned Lease to contain Four Acres, and are particularly mentioned in the Second Part of the said Second Schedule; and that the said Farms of Frifton and Crowlink, and also the said Farm of Exceate otherwise Exceit, except such Parts thereof as aforesaid, should remain in the Possession of and be limited to the Use of the said Henry Hall Viscount Gage, his Heirs and Assigns, during the Lives of the Persons who are named as Cestui que vies in the said first recited Indenture of Lease,1 and the Lives and Life of the Survivors and Survivor of them, at and under the like Yearly Rent and subject to the like Provisoes, Covenants, and Agreements as the said Parsonage, Tithes, Lands, and Hereditaments demised by the same Indenture of Lease are now subject to under or by virtue of the same Indenture of Lease; and that the said Two Pieces of Land containing together Six Acres, being respectively Parts of the Exceit Cow Down and of the said Piece of Land called Hog Brook, should remain in the Possession of and be limited to the Use of the said Henry Hall Viscount Gage, his Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, for the like Term of Years as is now to come and unexpired in the said Lands and Hereditaments

and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That all that the Parsonage of Firle otherwise West Firle in the County of Sussex, with all and singular the Tenements, Gardens, Gate-rooms, Barns, and other Edifices, Glebe Lands, Meadows, Pastures, Feedings, Tithes, Tenths, Oblations, Obventions, Emoluments, Rents, Casualties, Profits, Commodities, and Advantages, with the Appurtenances whatsoever to the said Parsonage belonging (save and except the said Piece or Parcel of Land at Exceit, mentioned in the said secondly recited Lease to contain Four Acres, and save also and exceptr the Advowson of the Vicarage of the Church of Firle otherwise West Firle aforesaid), and which Parsonage, Glebe Lands, Tithes, and Hereditaments, except as aforesaid, are described in the First and Second Parts of the First Schedule to this Act annexed, and the Freehold and Inheritance of the said several Hereditaments in Fee Simple, (except as before excepted), and the Reversion and Reversions, Remainder and Remainders, yearly and other Rents, Issues, and Profits thereof respectively, shall, immediately from and after the passing of this Act, be settled upon and limited to, and the same are hereby settled upon and limited to the said Henry Hall Viscount Gage, his Heirs and Assigns for ever, freed and discharged, and absolutely acquitted and exonerated of, from, and against all Estate, Right, Title, Interest, Claim and Demand whatsoever of the said Dean and Chapter or their Successors, into, from, out of, or upon the same several Hereditaments or any Part thereof; and also of and from all charitable or other Uses, Trusts, Intents, and Purposes, for and on the Behalf of the said Dean and Chapter, and for any other Person or Persons, or any other Purpose or Purposes whatsoever, to, upon, or subject to which the said Parsonage, Tithes, Lands, and other Hereditaments are or were held by the said Dean and Chapter at or immediately before the Time of the passing of this Act, but subject to the repairing from Time to Time and for ever hereafter, of the Chancel of the Church of Firle otherwise West Firle aforesaid.

Indemnity

III. And whereas Sir William Gage Baronet, long since deceased, by a Renter Codicil to his Will, bearing Date the Twentieth Day of January One of50/ drSe thousand seven hundred and thirty-seven, gave to John Board Esquire a yearly Rent-charge of Fifty Pounds, chargeable upon all his Manors, Lands, and Hereditaments: And whereas it does not appear that any Payment has been made on account of the said Rent-charge, or any Claim made in respect thereof, since the Death of the said Sir William Gage, and although it is presumed, that the Hereditaments charged with the said Rent-charge have been released therefrom, yet no Evidence of such Release can be produced : Be it therefore further enacted, That if at any Time or Times hereafter, any Action, Suit, Claim, or Demand shall be brought against or made upon the said Dean and Chapter, or their Successors, or their Lessee or Lessees for the Time being, of the Lands and Hereditaments described in the said Second Schedule to this Act, or any of them, or a ny Entry made into or upon the same Lands and Hereditaments, or any of them, by the Heirs or Assigns of the said John Board, or by any Person or Persons claiming by, from, through, or under him or them in respect of the said Rent-charge of Fifty Pounds, and the said Dean and Chapter or their Successors, or their Lessee or Lessees, shall in consequence of any such Action, Suit, Claim, Demand, or Entry, be obliged to pay or allow the said Rent-charge, or any Sum or Sums of Money on account thereof, or shall sustain any other Damage by reason of any such Action, Suit, Claim, Demand, or Entry, or incur any Costs in defending or prosecuting any Action or Suit, or other legal Proceeding on account thereof, it shall and may be lawful for the said Dean and Chapter, and their Successors, and their Lessee or Lessees from Time to Time, or at any Time, to enter into or upon the Lands and other Hereditaments comprised in the First Schedule to this Act, and to distrain for so much of the said Rent-charge as the said Dean and Chapter, or their Successors, or their Lessee or Lessees, shall or may be so obliged to pay, or shall so allow the Payment of, together with all such Damages and Costs as aforesaid, and the Costs of making such Distress, in such and the same Manner as Landlords are by Law entitled in case of Distress taken for Rent in Arrear, on common Demise; any thing herein-before contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 18.

An Act for enabling the President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society to purchase from the Corporation and other Persons entitled thereto the Lands and Hereditaments in the Parish of Saint George the Martyr, Southwark, in the County of Surrey, upon which they have erected a Chapel, Buildings, and other Works, and such other Land adjoining thereto as may be required for the Purposes of their Charity.

[17th June 1823.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Forty-sixth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act for establishing and well-governing the Charitable In* 46G.3.C. 144. stitution, commonly called The Philanthropic Society, formed for the Protection of poor Children, the Offspring of convicted Felons, and for the Reformation of Children who have themselves been engaged in Criminal Practices, and for incorporating the Subscribers thereto, and for the better empowering and enabling them to carry on their charitable and useful Designs; and certain Persons were thereby made one Body Corporate and Politic by the Name and Style of “ The President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society/’ and were thereby empowered to purchase, take, or receive, hold and enjoy, any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments for fPrivate.] 3 g erecting

274

Incorporated Persons may sell Lands to the Charity.

4° GEORGII IV. Cap. 18.

erecting and making a Chapel, Buildings, and other Works for the Purposes of the said Charity: And whereas the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, have erected and made a Chapel, Buildings, and other Works for the Purposes of the said Charity, upon Ground in Saint George's Fields, in the Parish of Saint George the Martyr, Southwark, in the County of Surrey, held by them upon Leases for Terms of Years, granted by the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London : And whereas, in order to render permanent the Benefits of the said Charity, it is desirable that the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, should be empowered to purchase from the Corporation or Corporations, or Person or Persons entitled thereto, the Freehold and Inheritance in Fee Simple of the Ground upon which the said Chapel, Buildings, and other Works have been erected, and of such other Ground adjoining thereto as may be required for the Purposes of the said Charity: But as the same cannot be effected without the Aid of Parliament, may it please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That it shall be lawful for all Bodies Politic, Corporate and Collegiate, and all Corporations whatsoever. Feoffees in Trust for Charitable and other Purposes, Executors, and Administrators, Tenants in Tail or for Life, Guardians, Committees, Husbands, and all other Trustees whomsoever, not only for and on Behalf of themselves, their Successors and Heirs, but also for and on Behalf of their Cestuique Trusts or Wards respectively, whether Infants, or Issue unborn, Lunatics, Idiots, Femes Covert, or other Person or Persons under any Disability or Incapacity of acting for himself, herself, or themselves, and also for all Femes Covert who are or shall be seised, possessed, or interested in their own Right, or entitled to Dower or other Interest therein, and for all Persons whether Tenants for Life, in Tail General or Special, or for Years determinable on any Life or Lives, and for all and every Persons or Person whomsoever who are, is, or shall be seised, possessed of, or interested in the Lands, Grounds, Chapel, Buildings, Works, and Hereditaments now used for the Purposes of the said Charity, or any of them, or any Lands or Grounds, Buildings or Hereditaments adjoining to the same, which the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society shall think necessary and proper to be purchased for the Purposes of the said Charity, not exceeding in the whole Two thousand five hundred superficial Yards, to treat and agree with the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, or their Successors, for the absolute Sale thereof, for any Sum or Sums of Money, or such other Consideration as herein-after is mentioned, and to convey the same to the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, and their Successors, for the Purposes of the said Charity, and every such Conveyance shall be made according to the following Form:

4 J A.B. of in Consideration of the Sum of to me paid, and (if any) of the Surrender of certain Leasehold Tenements by the President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, acting by virtue of an Act of Parliament passed in the Fourth Year of the Reign of His

And if the Premises are Leasehold for Years, they shall be assigned by a Form answerable to the above, only substituting the Words applicable to the Assignment of a Chattel; and all such Bodies Politic, Corporate, Collegiate, Corporations Aggregate or Sole, Feoffees in Trust, Executors, Administrators, Guardians, Committees of Idiots and Lunatics, and Husbands, and all other Persons, shall be and are hereby indemnified for what they shall do by virtue or in pursuance of this Act.

II. And be it further enacted, That immediately after the Execution Estates con-of every such Conveyance as aforesaid, the said President, Vice-Presi- veyed to vest dents. Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, and their President, Successors, shall be deemed in Law to be in the actual Seisin or Pos- dents^Trea session of the Lands, Grounds, Chapel, Buildings, Works, and other surer,’and Hereditaments conveyed to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever, as fully Members, and effectually as if every Person having an Estate, Right, Title, or Interest in the Premises had actually conveyed the same by Lease and Release, Bargain and Sale enrolled, Feoffment and Livery of Seisin, Fine,

Common Recovery, Surrender, or any other Conveyance or Assurance in Law whatsoever.

III. And be it further enacted, That in case any of the Leasehold Lands and Tenements now held by the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, or any Person or Persons in Trust for them, shall not be deemed by them to be necessary for the Purposes of their said Charity, it shall be lawful for them to surrender, or cause to be surrendered, such Lands or Tenements, or any Part or Parts thereof, which may not be deemed necessary for the Purposes aforesaid, to the Lessor or Lessors, or Owner or Owners of the Reversion of the same Lands or Tenements, and any Body or Bodies Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, or other Corporation or Corporations, who may be such Lessor or Lessors, or the Owner or Owners of such Reversion, are hereby authorized and empowered, if they shall think proper, to accept and take such Surrender, as the Consideration, or Part of the Consideration, for the Purchase of any other Lands or Hereditaments, which may be sold and conveyed by such Corporation or Corporations respectively by virtue of this Act.

The Society may surrender Lands as Part of the Consideration for the Purchase of other Lands.

IV. And be it further enacted, That if there shall be any Money to Application be paid for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments by of Purchase virtue of the Powers of this Act, for the Purposes thereof, which shall Money belong to any Body Politic, Corporate or Collegiate, or to any Corporation

276‘

Less than 200/. and amounting to 20/.

4° GEORGII IV. Cap. 18.

■poration whatsoever, or to any Feoffee in Trust, Executor, Administrator, Husband, Guardian, Committee, or other Trustee, for or on Behalf of any Infant, Lunatic, Idiot, Feme Covert, or other Cestuique Trust or Ward, or to any Person whose Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments are limited in strict or other Settlement, or to any Person under any other Disability or Incapacity whatsoever, such Money shall, in case the same shall amount to or exceed the Sum of Two hundred Pounds, with all convenient Speed be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the High Court of Chancery, to be placed to his Account there, ex-parte the President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, pursuant to the Method prescribed by the Act of the Twelfth Year of King George the First, Chapter Thirty-two, and the General Orders of the said Court, and without Fee or Reward, and some one of the Cashiers of the said Bank shall give a Receipt for the Money so paid, which shall be a sufficient Discharge for the same; and such Money shall be applied, under the Direction and with the Approbation of the said Court, to be signified by an Order made upon a Petition to be preferred in a summary Way by the Corporation or Corporations, or Person or Persons who would have been entitled to the Rents and Profits of the said Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, in the Purchase or Redemption of the Land Tax, or Discharge of any Debt or Debts, or such other Incumbrances or Part thereof as the said Court shall authorize to be paid, affecting the same Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or affecting other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, standing settled therewith to the same or the like Uses, Intents, or Purposes; or where such Money shall not be so applied, then the same shall be laid out and invested, under the like Direction and Approbation of the said Court, in the Purchase of other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, which shall be conveyed and settled to, for, and upon such and the like Uses, Trusts, Intents, and Purposes, and in the same Manner as the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments which shall be so purchased as aforesaid stood settled or limited, or such of them as at the Time of making such Conveyance and Settlement shall be existing undetermined and capable of taking effect; and in the meantime, and until such Purchase shall be made, the said Money shall, by Order of the said Court, upon Application thereto, be invested by the said Accountant General in his Name in the Purchase of Three Pounds per Centum per Annum Reduced Bank Annuities, or Three Pounds per Centum Consolidated Bank Annuities; and in the meantime, and until the same Bank Annuities shall be ordered by the said Court to be sold for the Purposes aforesaid, the Dividends and annual Produce of the said Bank Annuities shall from Time to Time be paid, by Order of the said Court, to the Corporation or Corporations or Person or Persons who would for the Time being have been entitled to the Rents and Profits of the said Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, to be purchased and settled by virtue of this Act, in case such Purchase and Settlement were made.

V. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if any Money agreed to be paid for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments as aforesaid, and belonging to any Corporation, or to any Person or Persons under any Disability or Incapacity as aforesaid, or which shall be limited in strict or other Settlement, shall be less than the

Sum

4* GEORGII IV. 18. 277

Sum of Two hundred Pounds, and shall exceed or be equal to the Sum of Twenty Pounds, then and in all such Cases the same shall, at the Option of the Corporation or Corporations, or Person or Persons who would have been entitled to the Rents and Profits of the Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments so purchased, or of his, her, or their Guardian or Guardians, Committee or Committees, or Trustee or Trustees, to be signified in Writing under their respective Hands, to be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the said Accountant General of the High Court of Chancery, and be placed to his Account as aforesaid, in order to be applied in the Manner herein-before directed (One of the Cashiers of the said Bank giving a Receipt for the said Money, which shall be a sufficient Discharge for the same), or otherwise the same shall be paid at the like Option to Two Trustees to be nominated by the Party making such Option, and approved of by the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members, or their Successors (such Nomination and Approbation to be signified in Writing under the Hands or Seals of the nominating and approving Parties), and the Money so paid to such Trustees shall be by them applied in any Manner herein-before directed with respect to the Money so to be paid as aforesaid into the Bank in the Name of the Accountant General of the said Court of Chancery, but without any Order of the said Court touching the Application thereof.

VI. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That if any Money agreed Less than to be paid for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments 20/. as aforesaid, and belonging to any Corporation, or to any Person or Persons under any Disability or Incapacity as aforesaid, shall be less than the Sum of Twenty Pounds, then and in all such Cases the same shall be paid to the Corporation or Corporations, or Person or Persons who would for the Time being have been entitled to the Rents and Profits of the Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, in respect whereof the same shall be paid, for his, her, or their own Use and Benefit, or to his, her, or their Guardian or Guardians, Committee or Committees, or Trustee or Trustees, for the Use and Benefit of such Person or Persons so entitled respectively; and the Receipt or Receipts of the Corporation or Corporations, or Person or Persons to whom the same shall be paid, shall be a sufficient Discharge or sufficient Discharges for the same.

VII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That if any Question shall arise touching the Title of any Corporation or Corporations, Person or Persons, to any Money to be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery, in pursuance of this Act, for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or of any Estate, Right, Title, Charge, or Interest therein, or of any Bank Annuities to be purchased with any such Money, or the Dividends and Interest of any such Bank Annuities, the Corporation or Corporations, Person or Persons, who shall have been in the Possession of such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, Estates, Interests, and Charges, at the Time of such Purchase, and all Corporations or Persons claiming under or under the Possession of such Corporation or Corporations, Person or Persons, shall be deemed and taken to have been lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, Estates, Interests, or Charges, according to such Possession, [Private.'] 4 y until

Doubt upon the Title, the Interest of the Money paid into the Bank shall be paid to the Person who was in the Possession of the Premises when bought.

until the contrary shall be shewn to the Satisfaction of the said Court of Chancery, and the Dividends or Interest of the Bank Annuities to be purchased with such Money, and also the Capital of such Bank Annuities, shall be paid, applied, and disposed of accordingly, unless it shall be made appear to the said Court that such Possession was a wrongful Possession, and that some other Person or Persons was or were lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or to some Estate or Interest therein, or Charge thereon.

Power to sell any of the Leasehold Estates or Lands to be purchased which may not be wanted.

VIII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That where by reason of any Disability or Incapacity of the Person or Persons, or Corporation entitled to any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, to be purchased under the Authority of this Act, the Purchase Money for the same shall be required to be paid into the Court of Chancery, and to be applied in the Purchase of other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, to be settled to the like Uses in pursuance of this Act, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court of Chancery, to order the Expences of all Purchases from Time to Time to be made in pursuance of this Act, or so much of the said Expences as to the said Court shall seem reasonable, to be paid by the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, or their Successors, who shall from Time to Time pay such Sums of Money for such Purposes as the said Court shall direct.

IX. And be it further enacted, That in case any of the Leasehold Lands and Tenements now held by the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, or any Person or Persons in Trust for them, or any Lands or Hereditaments to be purchased by virtue of this Act, shall not be deemed necessary by the said President, Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, and Members of the Philanthropic Society, for the Purposes of their said Charity, then and in every such Case, it shall and may be lawful for them to sell and dispose of the same in such Manner, and for such Price or Prices as they shall think proper.

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 19.

An Act to empower the Judges of the Court of Session to take an Account of the Debts and Burdens affecting, and that may be made to affect, the Entailed Estate of Wemyss, in the Counties of Fife and Perth; and to sell the said Estate, or such Part thereof as shall be sufficient to discharge the said Debts and Burdens.

[17th June 1823.]

and for carrying into Execution the said Sales, the Judges of the said Court of Session in either the Divisions thereof, shall be and are hereby authorized and required to take Proofs of the Values of the said Estate, or of such Parts and Portions of the said entailed Estate hereby authorized to be sold, as shall or may be judged most proper to be disposed of; III. And be it enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That after the Sale or Sales aforesaid shall be accomplished, and the Purchase Money paid or consigned as aforesaid, the said Court shall proceed to adjust the Claims of the Creditors whose Debts or Claims affect or may be made to affect the said Estate, and issue their Warrants or Decreets for the Payment thereof, and for paying the necessary Charges of the Proceedings; every such Creditor or Claimant, upon receiving Payment, being obliged to execute a complete Discharge of his or her Debt or Claim, to the Extent of* the Sum or Sums paid, and the several Discharges shall be registered in the Books of the Court of Session or Record of Sasines if requisite.

IV. Provided always, and be it enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That in case a Surplus shall remain of the Price of the Lands so to be sold under the Authority of this Act, and Interest thereof, after defraying the Expences of passing this Act, and all the reasonable Expences which may be incurred in carrying the same into Execution, and after Payment of all the Debts and Obligations of the said William Wemyss, to be ascertained in Manner before directed, the Judges of the said Court of Session in either of the Divisions thereof are hereby empowered and required to direct and order that the said Surplus shall be laid out and employed in the Purchase of other Lands, which shall be limited and settled to the same Uses and Purposes, and under the like prohibitory, irritant, and resolutive Clauses as the said Lands and Estate of WemysS, by the Deed of Entail herein-before recited, now stand limited and settled; and in the meantime, and until the Money shall be so applied, to order and direct that the same shall remain in the Bank of Scotland, or Royal Bank of Scotland, or Bank of the British Linen Company of Scotland, subject to the Direction of the Court of Session in either the Divisions thereof in the Names of such Persons as the Court shall have appointed as aforesaid, who shall annually receive the highest Interest which can be got for the same; and the Interest arising from the Money so paid in shall be laid out in the Name or Names of such Persons as aforesaid, and shall annually accumulate and be added to the Principal Sum, so that they may carry Interest together until a proper Purchase in Lands shall be found, to be limited in the Manner herein before directed, and until, upon a Petition to be preferred to the said Court of Session in either of the Divisions thereof, in a summary Way, by the said James Wemyss, or any Heir of Entail in Possession of the said Estate, the Money shall be ordered to be paid by the Treasurer of the Bank of Scotland, or the Cashier of the Royal Bank of Scotland, or the Manager of the Bank of the British Linen Company of Scotland, for completing the said Purchase in such Manner as the said Court shall direct.

V. Provided always, That if the Money arising by the principal and accumulated Interest of such Sum or Sums shall exceed the Amount of the Purchase Money so paid into the said Bank of Scotland, or Royal Bank of Scotland, or Bank of the British Linen Company of

Scotland,

4° GEORGII IV. Cap. 19.

Scotland, then and in that Case only the Surplus which shall remain, after discharging the Expence of the Application to the Com t, shall be paid to the Person or Persons who for the Time being would be entitled to receive the Rents and Profits of the Lands directed to be purchased, in case the same had been purchased pursuant to this Act, or the Representatives of such Person or Persons.

VI. And be it enacted, That the Costs and Charges of all Proceedings charges of to be had in either of the Divisions of the Court of Session, in pur- the Proceed-suance of the Powers given by this Act, shall be taxed and ascer- ,n?^to e tained according to the Practice of the said Court.

VII. And be it enacted, That the said James Wemyss, or the Heir of Heirs of En-Entailin Possession of the said entailed Estate of Wemyss for the Time, ^ll not to wish all not incur any Irritancy or Forfeiture for or by reason of his ^cy°y executing any Disposition or other Deed directed to be executed under the Authority of this Act.

VIII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That none of the Provisions of this Act shall take place, nor shall the said Act be carried into Execution unless James Wemyss, the Younger Son of the said James WemysSy who was the Third Son of the said James Earl of* WemysSy shall, if in Life, and as soon as he shall be served with a Copy of this Act, by a Deed or Deeds executed by him before Two attesting Witnesses, express his Consent for himself, and as Administrator in Law for his several Sons under Age, to this Act; and in case of the Death of the said James Wemyss before giving his Consent, the Consent of the legal Guardian or Guardians of his Sons under Age, given in the same Manner, shall be requisite; and such Deed or Deeds shall be registered in the Court of Session, and shall in all Time thereafter be held and taken to be sufficient Evidence of the said James Wemyss having consented as aforesaid to the passing of this Act, as if his Consent had been previously given, and be binding on him and his Issue Male in all Time thereafter.

James

necessary.

IX. Saving and reserving unto the King’s most Excellent Majesty, Saving His Heirs and Successors, and to all and every other Person or Persons, Clause. Bodies Politic and Corporate, and the Creditors on the said Estate, who may be unpaid, (excepting the said James Wemyss, and the Heirs of Entail entitled by virtue of the said before recited Deed of Entail to succeed to and take the said Estate of Wemyss,) all such Right, Title, Interest, Claim, and Demand, in and to or out of all or any Part of the said Lands and Estate, or the Monies to accrue by the Sale thereof, according as they, any, or either of them have or might have any Claim, Challenge, or Demand, in or to the same, in case this Act had never been made.

X. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by Act to be the several Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, duly printed by authorized to print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a His Majes-Copy thereof so printed by any of them, shall be admitted’as Evi- ty’s Printers‘ dence thereof by all Judges, Justices, and others.

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 20.

An Act for vesting in Trustees an Estate in the Parish of Cliievely in the County of Berks, devised in strict Settlement by the Will of William Capel Esquire, deceased, and afterwards contracted to be sold by him, in order to effectuate the Sale thereof, agreeably to such Contract.

[17th June 1823.]

WHEREAS William Capel, late of P rest bury in the County of Will of

Gloucester, Esquire, deceased, by his last Will and Testament, W.Capel Esq. duly signed and published in the Presence of Three subscribing Witnesses, bearing Date the Nineteenth Day of August in the-Year One thousand eight hundred and seventeen, after disposing of his Wines and Liquors, Household Goods and Furniture, and devising his Estates at Prestbury aforesaid to Susanna Capel his Widow, for her Life, and giving certain Hereditaments and Premises in the City of Gloucester, and at Bishops Cleeve in the County of Gloucester, in Trust to be sold, and bequeathing several pecuniary Legacies, and an Annuity, gave and devised all his Messuages, Lands, and Hereditaments at Prestbury aforesaid, subject to the Estate for Life of the said Susanna Capel therein; and also all other his Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments whatsoever and wheresoever, not thereinbefore disposed of, unto Joseph Watts of Stroud in the County of Gloucester, common Brewer, his Heirs and Assigns, to the Use of the Testator’s eldest Son, Christopher Capel for his Life; Remain-[Private.'] */ der

298

4° GEOR<jII IV. 20.

der to the Use of the said Joseph Watts and his Heirs, during the Life of the said Christopher Capel, to preserve contingent Remainders; with Remainder to the Use of the said Joseph Watts, his Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, for the Term of One thousand Years, for raising Portions for the Daughters of the said Christopher Capel; Remainder to the Use of the First and other Sons of the said Christopher Capel, successively in Tail Male; Remainder to the Use of the Testator’s Son William Capaf, for his Life; Remainder to the Use of the said Joseph Watts, and his Heirs, during the Life of the said William Capel the Son, to preserve contingent Remainders; Remainder to the Use of the First and other Sons of the said William Capel the Son, successively in Tail Male; Remainder to the Use of the Testator’s Son Daniel Capel, for his Life; Remainder to the Use of the said Joseph Watts and his Heirs, during the Life of the said Daniel Capel, to preserve contingent Remainders; Remainder to the Use of the First and other Sons of the said Daniel Capel successively in Tail Male; Remainder to the Use of the Testator’s Son George Capel for his Life; Remainder to the Use of the said Joseph Watts and his Heirs, during the Life of the said George Capel, to preserve contingent Remainders; Remainder to the Use of the First and other Sons of the said George Capel successively in Tail Male; Remainder to the Use of the Testator’s Son John Capel, for his Life; Remainder to the Use of the said Joseph Watts and his Heirs, during the Life of the said John Capel, to preserve contingent Remainders; Remainder to the Use of the First and other Sons of the said John Capel successively in Tail Male; Remainder to the Use of the Testater’s Son Samuel Richard Capel, for his Life; Remainder to the Use of the said Joseph Watts and his Heirs, during the Life of the said Samuel Richard Capel, to preserve contingent Remainders; Remainder to the Use of the First and other Sons of the said Samuel Richard Capel successively in Tail Male; with Remainder to the Use of the said Testator’s own right Heirs; and the said Testator gave all the Rest of his Goods, Chattels, Personal Estate, and Effects whatsoever, not thereinbefore specifically bequeathed, unto the said Susanna Capel, Joseph Watts, Christopher Capel, and Daniel Capel, upon Trust, after Payment of his the said Testator’s Debts, Funeral and Testamentary Expences, and discharging certain specific Sums thereout, to invest the Residue thereof upon Government or other Public Stocks, Funds, or Securities, or upon Real Securities at Interest, and pay unto or permit the said Testator’s Wife and her Assigns to receive the Whole of the said Dividends, Interest, and Proceeds thereof, for her Life, in case she should so long continue his Widow; and after her Decease or Marriage, which should first happen, then upon Trust, that they the said Trustees, and the Survivors and Survivor of them, and the Executors or Administrators of such Survivor, did and should pay or assign and transfer the Whole of the said Trust Monies, Funds, and Securities unto or between and among all and every or such One or more of the Children of the said Testator or their Children, either exclusively, or in such Parts, Shares, or Proportions, to become vested or payable at such Time or Times, either absolutely or conditionally, and subject to such Provisoes or Limitations over (such Provisoes and Limitations over to be for the Benefit of some or one of the said Testator’s Children or Grand-children) and in such Manner and Form in all respects as the said Testator’s said Wife, if she should continue his Widow, by Deed or Will to be executed as therein mentioned should appoint; but in case of her Second Marriage, and in default of any such Appointment,

and the said Testator appointed the said Susanna Capel, Joseph Watts, Christopher Capel, and Daniel Capet, Executors of his said Will: And whereas the said William Capel, the Testator, afterwards duly made and published a Codicil to his said Will, in the Presence of Three subscribing Witnesses, bearing Date the Twenty-fourth Day of September, in the said Year One thousand eight hundred and seventeen, whereby he gave certain Directions as to his residuary Personal Estate, but did not therein make any Disposition of any Part of his Real Estate : And whereas in and by certain Articles of Agreement, bearing Date the Twenty-seventh Day of May in the said Year One thousand eight hundred and eighteen, and made between the said Christopher Capel, for and on behalf of the said William Capel, the Testator, of the one Part, and Joseph Bartholomew of Aldsworth in the County of Berks, Esquire, of the other Part, the said Christopher Capel, on behalf of the said William Capel, the Testator, agreed in Consideration of the Sum of Twenty-four thousand Pounds, to be paid in the Manner therein-after mentioned, to sell to the said Joseph Bartholomew, for an Estate in Fee Simple in Possession, free from all Incumbrances whatsoever, all those Farms called Chievley Farm and Radnalls Farm \ and all the Messuages, Lands, Cottages, Hereditaments and Premises in the Parish of Chievley in the said County of Berks, then in the Occupation of the said Joseph Bartholomew and George Burgess; and also all those Woods called Phillips Hill and Hasel Hanger, then in Hand, and situate in the said Parish of Chievley : And whereas, after having entered into the said Contract, the said Testator, William Capel, made and published another Codicil to his said Will, in the Presence of Three subscribing Witnesses, bearing Date the Sixth Day of June in the Year One thousand eight hundred and eighteen, whereby, after reciting the said Sale so made by him as aforesaid, the said Testator declared his Will to be, that Six thousand Pounds, Part of the said Purchase Money for the said Estate so contracted to be sold, should sink into the Residuum of his Personal Estate, as disposed of by his Will; and that the rest of the said Purchase Money should go and belong to the same Persons, for the same Estates and Interests, as that Estate would have gone if it had not been sold : And whereas the said Testator, William Capel, departed this Life in or about the Month of October in the said Year One thousand eight hundred and eighteen, without having executed any Conveyance of the said Estate at Chievley, so as aforesaid contracted to be sold by him, and without having revoked or altered his said Will, otherwise than as herein-before mentioned, and without having in any respect revoked or altered his said Codicils, or either of them, leaving the said Susanna Capel his Widow, the said Christopher Capel his eldest Son and Heir at Law, and the said William Capel, Daniel Capel, George Capel, John Capel, and Samuel Richard Capel, his only other Children: And whereas the said Christopher Capel, in the Month of April in the Year One thousand eight hundred and twenty-one, intermarried with Elizabeth Forbes, by whom he hath Issue One Son only, to wit, Christopher Capel, an Infant under the Age of one Year: And whereas neither the said William Capel the Son, nor the said Daniel Capel, George Capel, John Capel, and Samuel Richard Capel, or either of them, have any Issue Male : And whereas the said Estate at Chievley, so as aforesaid contracted to be sold by the said William Capel

the Testator, after the Date of his said Will, being comprized in the General Devise in the said Will of all the rest of the said Testator’s Real Estate not therein-before disposed of, and the said Contract for Sale, having only operated as a Revocation in Equity of the Devise of the said Premises so contracted for, the same Premises on the Death of the said William Capel the Testator, notwithstanding the said Contract, remained and continued at Law subject and liable to the Limitations contained in the said Will; and by virtue thereof the said Christopher Capel the Infant is now seised as Tenant in Tail Male of the legal Estate of and in the same Messuages, Farms, Lands, and Hereditaments so as aforesaid contracted to be sold by the said Testator, subject to the precedent Estates thereof limited in and by the said Will: And whereas, by reason of the Infancy of the said Christopher Capel, the legal Tenant in Tail of the said Estate, so contracted for as aforesaid, the said Christopher Capel the elder, William Capel the Son, Daniel Capel, George Capel, John Capel, and Samuel Richard Capel, and the said Susanna Capel, and Joseph Watts, are unable to make an effectual Conveyance of the legal Fee of the said Estate to the Purchaser thereof, without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: Therefore Your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal Subjects, the said Christopher Capel the elder, on behalf of himself and the said Christopher Capel his Infant Son, and the said Susanna Capel, Joseph Watts, Daniel Capel, William Capel the Son, George Capel, John Capel, and Samuel Richard Capel, do most humbly beseech Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That all and singular the said Messuages or Tenements, several Closes, Pieces, and Parcels of Arable Land, Meadow, and Pasture Ground, called Chievley Farm and Radnalls Farm, and the said Woods called Phillips Hill and Hazel Hanger, and in the Schedule to this Act more particularly mentioned and described, all situate in the Parish of Chievley aforesaid, in the said County of Berks, and so as aforesaid contracted to be sold by the said William Capel deceased, to the said Joseph Bartholomew, together with all and every their Rights, Members, and Appurtenances, and the Reversion and Reversions, Remainder and Remainders, Rents, Issues, and Profits thereof, and of every Part thereof, shall from and immediately after the passing of this Act be absolutely vested in the said Joseph Watts and Christopher Capel the elder, and their Heirs, to the Use of them the said Joseph Watts and Christopher Capel the elder, their Heirs and Assigns for ever, freed and absolutely v^Uof^the16 acclu^t:e^» exonerated, and discharged of and from all and every the Uses, said William Estatess Limitations, Charges, Trusts, Powers, Provisoes, Declarations, and Capel, de- Agreements, in and by the said Will of the said William Capel, deceased, limited, expressed, declared, and contained of and concerning the same, or any Part or Parts thereof; but nevertheless upon the Trusts, and to and for the Ends, Intents, and Purposes herein-after expressed and declared of and concerning the same, that is to say, upon Trust that they the said Joseph Watts and Christopher Capel the elder, or the Survivor of them, or the Heirs or Assigns of such Survivor, do and shall as soon as conveniently may be after the passing of this Act, upon Payment by the said Joseph Bartholomew, his Heirs or Assigns, of the Purchase Money for the same, in Manner herein-after mentioned, convey and assure the said Messuages, Lands, Hereditaments, and Premises, unto him the said Joseph Bartholomew, his Appointee or Appointees, or his or their Heirs and Assigns, or in such other

II. And be it further enacted, That when the said Purchase Money for the said Messuages, Lands, Hereditaments, and Premises, shall be paid by the said Joseph Bartholomew, his Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the High Court of Chancery, to be placed to his Account there, “ ex parte the Purchaser of the Estate of the late William Capel deceased,” pursuant to the Method prescribed by the Act of the Twelfth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the First, Chapter the Thirty-second, and the General Orders of the said Court, and without Fee or Reward, according to the Act of the Twelfth Year of the Reign of King George the Second, Chapter the Twenty-fourth; and as soon as may be s&ter such Monies shall have been so paid as aforesaid, the same shall, upon a Petition to be preferred to the said Court of Chancery in a summary Way by the said Christopher Capel, on behalf of himself and his said Infant Son, and by the said Susanna Capel, Joseph Watts, Christopher Capel, and Daniel Capel, or the Survivors or Survivor of them, as Devisees of the Residuary Personal Estate of the said Testator, be applied, laid out, and invested under the Order and with the Approbation of the said Court, agreeably to the Directions, and according to the Trusts expressed and declared of and concerning the said Purchase Money, in and by the said last herein-before mentioned Codicil of the said William Capel, the Testator.

III. And be it further enacted, That all Sum and Sums of Money which shall be paid into the Bank in the Name of the said Accountant General, for the Purchase of the said Premises, or so much thereof as shall not be ordered by the said Court of Chancery to be applied in the Payment of the Costs and Expences according to the Provisions herein contained, shall in the meantime and until the same Monies shall be respectively applied and invested, be from Time to Time laid out by the said Accountant General in the Purchase of Navy or Victualling Bills or Exchequer Bills; provided that it shall and may be lawful for the said Court of Chancery to make such General Order or Orders, or Special Order or Orders, if necessary, that whensoever the Exchequer Bills of the Date of those in the Hands of the said Accountant General shall be in a Course of Payment by Government, and new Exchequer Bills shall be issued, such new Exchequer Bills may be received in exchange for those which are in a Course of Payment, as shall be effectual for enabling such Receipt in exchange, and that in that Event the Interest of the old Bills shall be laid out as before directed with respect to the Interest when the Bills are paid off*; all which said Navy and Victualling Bills and Exchequer Bills, whether purchased or exchanged, shall be deposited in the Bank in the Name of the said Accountant General, and shall there remain until the same shall, upon Petition to be preferred to the said Court in a summary Way by the Person or Persons who shall for the Time being be entitled to the Proceeds of the said Purchase Money, or by the Guardian or Guardians of such Person or Persons being an Infant or Infants, be ordered

IV. And be it further enacted, That the Certificate or Certificates of the said Accountant General, together with the Receipt or Receipts of One of the Cashiers of the Bank of England, to be thereto annexed, and therewith filed in the Register Office of the said Court of Chancery, of Payment into the Bank of England by the Purchaser or Purchasers of the said Hereditaments and Premises, or of any Part or Parts thereof, shall from Time to Time be a good and effectual Discharge to such Purchaser or Purchasers, and to his, her, or their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, for the said Purchase Monies, or so much thereof for which such Certificates and Receipts shall be respectively given; and after filing such Certificates and Receipts as aforesaid, such Purchaser or Purchasers, and his, her, and their respective Heirs, Executors, Administrators, and Assigns shall be absolutely acquitted and discharged of and from the said Monies, and shall not be answerable or accountable for any Loss, Misapplication, or Nomapplication thereof.

V. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the said Court of Chancery from Time to Time to make such Order, as the said Court shall think fir, for taxing and settling all Costs, Charges, and Expences which shall have been or shall be incurred in obtaining and passing this Act, and which have been incurred in the several Stages and Proceedings preparatory thereto, and in making the several Applications to the said Court of Chancery, in pursuance of this Act, and laying out and investing all or any of the Monies which under this Act shall be paid into the Bank of England, according to the Directions herein contained or otherwise, in carrying the Purposes of this Act into Execution; and also from Time to Time to make an Order, if to the same Court it shall seem fit, for the Payment of such last-mentioned Costs, Charges, and Expences, out of the Monies so to be paid into the said Bank as aforesaid, or out of the Money arising by the said Sale of the said Navy, Victualling, or Exchequer Bills.

VI. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if either of the said Trustees hereby appointed, or any future Trustee or Trustees who shall succeed, or shall be appointed in the Place or Stead of them or either of them, as herein-after is mentioned, shall die, or desire to be discharged from, or shall refuse or decline, or become incapable to act in the Trusts or Powers hereby reposed in them or him respectively, or shall go out of Great Britain before the said Trusts shall be fully performed and executed, then and so often as any such Case shall happen, it shall be lawful for the said Court of Chancery, in a summary Way, upon the Petition of the Person or Persons for the Time being entitled to the Dividends and Proceeds of the said Monies, or of the Guardian or Guardians of such Person or Persons being an Infant or Infants, from Time to Time to nominate and appoint any Person or Persons to be a Trustee or Trustees, in the Stead or Place of the Trustee or Trustees so dying or desiring to be discharged, or refusing or declining or becoming incapable to act, or going

4° GEORGII IV. Cap.20.

out of Great Britain as aforesaid; and when and so often as any Trustee or Trustees shall have been nominated and appointed in manner aforesaid, all the said Trust Estates which shall then be vested in the Trustee or Trustees so dying or desiring to be discharged, or refusing or declining or becoming incapable to act, or going out of Great Britain as aforesaid, either solely or jointly with the other Trustee of the same Trust Estates, shall thereupon, with all convenient Speed, be conveyed and assured in such Manner that the same may be legally and effectually vested in the surviving or continuing Trustee of the same Trust Estates and such new or other Trustee jointly, or in such new Trustees only, as the Case may require, upon the same Trusts, and for the same Intents and Purposes, as are herein-before expressed, declared, and contained, or so many of them as shall be then subsisting or capable of taking effect; and such new Trustee or Trustees shall and may in all things act in the Management and Execution of the Trusts hereby created, as fully and effectually, and with all the same Powers and Authorities, to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever, as if he or they had been originally by this Act nominated a Trustee or Trustees.

VII. Saving always to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs and Successors, and to all and every Person and Persons, Bodies Politic and Corporate, his, her, and their Heirs, Successors, Executors, and Administrators, (other than and except the said Christopher Capel the elder, the said Christopher Capel his Infant Son and the Heirs Male of his Body, and the said William Capel the Son, Daniel Capel, George Capel, John Capel, and Samuel Richard Capel, and their respective Sons, and the Heirs Male of their Bodies respectively, and also the said Susanna Capel and Joseph Watts, and all other Persons having or lawfully claiming, or who shall or may have or lawfully claim any Estate, Right, Title, Claim, or Interest under or by virtue of the said Will or Codicils of the said William Capel deceased,) all such Estate, Right, Title, Claim, and Interest, in, to, or out of the said Hereditaments and Premises hereby vested andkettled, as they and every or any of them had before the passing of this Act, or could or might have had, held, and enjoyed, in case this Act had not been passed.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, duly authorized to print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a Copy thereof so printed by any of them shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges, Justices, and others.

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 21.

An Act for exchanging certain Parts of the Estates devised by the Will of the late Sir William Guise Baronet, in strict Settlement for certain other Estates in the County of Gloucester; and for vesting other Parts of the said Estates in Trustees, to be sold for paying oft' Incumbrances, and for other Purposes.

[17th June 1823.]

WHEREAS Sir William Guise, formerly of Rendcomb Park in Will of the County of Gloucester, Baronet, by his last Will and Sir William Testament in Writing, bearing Date on or about the Twenty-first Day of March One thousand seven hundred and eighty-three, signed March 1783. and published by him in the Presence of Three subscribing Witnesses, after making certain specific Devises and Bequests, gave and devised all other his Manors, Messuages, Lands, Tenements, Rectories, Tithes,

Rents, Advowsons, and Hereditaments whatsoever not therein-before devised, whereof or wherein he or any other Person or Persons in Trust for him then had or was entitled to any Estate of Freehold or Inheritance, in Possession, Reversion, Remainder, or Expectancy, unto Sir William Codrington Baronet, and the Honourable Daines Barrington, and their Heirs, to the Intent that certain Persons therein named, and who are all since deceased, should, out of the same Manors, Messuages, Lands, Tenements, Rectories, Tithes, Rents, Advowsons, Hereditaments, and \_Private.~] 4 Premises,

III. And be it further enacted, That if any of the several Hereditaments herein-before respectively limited, settled, and assured by way of Exchange as aforesaid, shall at any Time or Times hereafter be lawfully recovered from, or taken out of the Possession of the Person or Persons in or upon whom or to whose Use the same Hereditaments are by this Act respectively vested or settled as aforesaid, or his or their respective Heirs or Assigns, by any Right or Title precedent to the passing of this Act, without the Neglect or Default of such Person or Persons, then and from thenceforth it shall and may be lawful to and for all and every the Person and Persons, and his or their Heirs or Assigns, out of whose Possession such Hereditaments shall be so lawfully recovered and taken away, from and immediately after such his or their Eviction from or Loss of the Possession of the said Hereditaments respectively, or any Part thereof as aforesaid, to enter into the several Hereditaments hereby settled and assured in lieu of and in Exchange for the said Hereditaments which shall be so lawfully recovered and taken away, and the same to have, hold, repossess, and enjoy, as in his, her, or their first and former Estate, any thing herein-before contained to the contrary thereof in anywise notwithstanding.

XI. And whereas the said Martin George Guise some Time since went abroad to South America, and his Consent to this Act hath not yet been proved; be it therefore enacted, That this Act shall not, nor shall any thing herein contained, be construed, deemed, or taken to affect, be conclusive upon, or in any Manner to bind the said Martin George Guise or his Issue Male, unless and until he the said Martin George Guise shall signify his Consent to this Act by Writing under his Hand, and attested by One or more Witness or Witnesses, which Writing shall be enrolled in the High Court of Chancery within Three Years from the Date thereof; and such Consent may be given in the Form or to the Effect following; (that is to say),

XII. Saving always to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs General and Successors, and to all and every Persons and Person, Bodies Politic ^avln&* and Corporate, his, her, and their Heirs, Successors, Executors, and Administrators (other than and except the said Sir Berkeley William Guise,

John Wright Guise, Powell Colchester Guise, Martin George Guise, and Elizabeth Frances Webby and the Sons of the said Sir Berkeley William Guise, John Wright Guise, Powell Colchester Guise, and Martin George Guise respectively, and the Heirs Male of the Body of such respective Sons issuing, and the Heirs of the Body of the said Elizabeth Frances Webb, and the Eleirs and Assigns of the said Sir Berkeley William Guise, and all other Persons claiming any Estate, Right, Title, or Interest under the Devises or Limitations contained in the said Wills of the said Sir William Guise and Sir John Guise, or either of them); except the Annuitants under the said Will of the said Sir William Guise, all such Estate,

Right, Title, Interest, Claim, and Demand of, in, to, and out of the Manors, Advowsons, Messuages, Farms, Lands, Tenements, and other Hereditaments hereby respectively limited, vested, settled, and assured as aforesaid, as they or any of them had before the passing of this Act, or could or might have had, held, or enjoyed, in case this Act had not been made.

XIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the Printed Act several Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, duly authorized to Evidence, print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a Copy thereof so printed

by any of them shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges,

Justices, and others.

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 22.

An Act for authorizing the Investment of Monies belonging to the Infant Sons of Sir Samuel Romilly deceased, in the Purchase of certain Parts of his Daughter’s Share of his Real Estate, to be conveyed to Trustees upon certain Trusts.

[27th June 1823.]

WHEREAS Sir Samuel Romilly, late of Russell Square in the County of Middlesex, Knight, deceased, duly made and published his last Will and Testament in Writing, bearing Date the Nineteenth Day of August One thousand eight hundred and fifteen, and executed in such Manner as by Law is required for passing Real Estates by Devise, whereby (amongst other Things) he appointed his Wife the Guardian of all his Children during her Life, but if she should die during the Minority of any of them, he appointed his good Friend John Whishaw of Lincoln's Inn Guardian of his Sons, and Mary Whittaker his Wife’s Sister Guardian of his Daughter; and the said Testator (after giving and bequeathing various specific and pecuniary Legacies) gave to his said Wife all his Freehold Estates not therein-before devised by him for the Term of her Life, and he gave her an absolute Power by Deed or Will to dispose of all such Estates in any Way that she might think fit; but in Default of her exercising that Power, he directed that his said Freehold Estates, or such Parts thereof as she should not have disposed of, should at her Death be divided into a Number of Shares equal to the Number of Children he should then have living and One more \ and [Private.'] 4 n that

that his then eldest Son should have Two such Shares, and each of his other Children One such Share, to them and their Heirs, as Tenants in Common, and the said Testator thereby appointed his said Wife Executrix of his said Will; And whereas the said Testator added a Codicil to his said Will, bearing Date the Twenty-seventh Day of March in the Year One thousand eight hundred and seventeen, and duly executed and attested for the Devise of Real Estates, whereby (after stating that since making his said Will, he had contracted to purchase from the Trustees of Lord Llandaff an Estate in Glamorganshire for Twenty-one thousand Pounds) the said Testator declared it to be his Will, that the said Purchase should be completed out of his Personal Estate, and that the said Estate should go to the same Uses and for the same Purposes as the Bulk of his Real Estates devised by his said in part recited Will: And whereas the said Testator added another Codicil to his said Will, duly executed and attested for the Devise of Real Estates, and bearing Date on or about the Fourth Day of October in the Year One thousand eight hundred and eighteen, whereby he directed that if his said Wife whom he had by his said Will appointed Guardian of his Children should die before him, he thereby appointed Colonel John Garbett Walsham to be such Guardian; and if he should happen to die during the Minority of any of his Children, or should from ill Health decline to take upon himself the Office of their Guardian, the said Testator in that Case appointed William Marquis of Lansdowne, and JohnlFhishaw, to be their Guardians; and the said Testator stated that he had purchased of the Trustees of Lord JLlandaff, and had had conveyed to him the said Estate in Glamorganshire, which he thereby devised to the same Uses as he had by his Will devised the Residue of his Real Estates: And whereas the said Testator added another Codicil to his said Will, whereby he appointed the said John Whishaw Executor of his Will, together with the Executors already named : And whereas the said Testator departed this Life in the Month of November in the Year One thousand eight hundred and eighteen, and the said Will and Codicils (together with other Codicils to his said Will not affecting the Devises herein-before contained, or the Appointments of Guardians and Executors herein-before stated) were, on or about the Second Day of January in the Year One thousand eight hundred and nineteen, duly proved by the said John Whishaw alone, in the Prerogative Court of the Archbishop of Canterbury, and all the Debts of the said Testator, and the Legacies and Annuities given by his said Will and Codicils, have been paid or provided for : And whereas Ann Romilly the Wife of the said Testator, and the Executrix and Devisee named in his said recited Will, departed this Life in the Life-time of the said Testator : And whereas the Marriage of the said Sir Samuel Romilly with Ann Garbett his said Wife took place on or about the Third Day of January in the Year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and ninety-eight, and at the Time of the Decease of the said Sir Samuel Romilly there were Seven Children of the said Marriage, namely, William Romilly the eldest Son and Heir at Law, Sophia Romilly now the Wife of Thomas Francis Kennedy Esquire, John Romilly, Edward Romilly, Henry Romilly, Charles Romilly, and Frederick Romilly, who at the Time of the Decease of the said Sir Samuel Romilly were all Infants under the Age of Twenty-one Years, and no other Issue : And whereas John Garbett Walsham Esquire of Knill Court in the County of Hereford, Brother in Law of the said Testator, (called in the said recited Will Colonel John Garbett Walshain) departed

John Whisbaw (as the Guardians of the said Edward Romilly, Henry Romilly, Charles Romilly, and Frederick Romilly the Infants) have been informed that it is probable that all the present vested Share or Shares of the said Sophia Kennedy of and in the Manors, Lands, and Hereditaments specified in the said First and Second Schedules to this Act will be sold and disposed of, and that the same could now be purchased at a Price not exceeding Twelve thousand five hundred Pounds for the whole thereof, and they are of Opinion that such Purchase would in itself be advantageous, and the more so to them the said John Romilly, Edward Romilly, Henry Romilly, Charles Romilly, and Frederick Romilly, as it would increase the Value of their original Shares of and in the same Hereditaments and Premises, and (that is to say), upon Trust that they the said Henry Marquis of Lansdowne and John Whishaw and the Survivor of them, his Heirs and Assigns, do and shall receive and take the Rents, Issues, and Profits of the said undivided Parts or Shares so to be vested in them as last mentioned, and pay and apply such Rents and Profits in equal Shares and Proportions unto or for the Use and Benefit of the said Edward Romilly, Henry Romilly, Charles Romilly, and Frederick Romilly respectively, until they shall respectively attain the Age of Twenty-one Years or die under that Age, and do and shall convey and assure to each and every of them the said Edward Romilly, Henry Romilly, Charles Romilly, and Frederick Romilly, upon his attaining the said Age of Twenty-one Years, and his Heirs and Assigns, One undivided Fourth Part or Share (the whole into Four equal Parts or Shares to be divided) of and in the said undivided Parts or Shares and Hereditaments herein-before directed to be vested in them the said Henry Marquis of Lansdowne and John Whishaw as aforesaid; but in case any One or more of them the said Edward Romilly, Henry Romilly, Charles Romilly, and Frederick Romilly, shall happen to die under the said Age of Twenty-one Years, then upon further Trust that they the said Henry Marquis of Lansdowne and John Whishawt or the Survivor of them, his Heirs or Assigns, do and shall absolutely make Sale and dispose of the Part or Share or Parts or Shares of the said Hereditaments hereby intended for each of the said Infant Persons as shall happen so to die under Age, either by public Auction or private Contract, to any Person or Persons who shall or may be willing to purchase the same, for the most Money and best Price or Prices that can or may be gotten for the same, and do and shall convey and assure the Part or Share or Parts or Shares so to be sold accordingly.

III. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for them the said Henry Marquis of Lansdowne and John Whishaw, or the Survivor of them, his Executors or Administrators, from Time to Time (if they or he shall think advisable so to do, and by and with the Approbation of the High Court of Chancery, to be obtained upon a Petition presented in a summary Way) to purchase any such Part

VII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the several Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, duly authorized to print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a Copy thereof so printed by any of them shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges, Justices, and others.
