ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 23.

An Act for inclosing .Lands within the Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, in the County of Leicester.

[27th June 1823.]

WHEREAS there are within the Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, in the several Parishes of Congerston otherwise Congeston, Nelson otherwise Nailstone, Market Bosworth, and Shaxton otherwise Shackston otherwise Shackerston, in the County of Leicester, divers Open and Common Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, containing in the whole by Estimation Nine hundred Acres or thereabouts: And whereas the Right Honourable Richard William Penn Earl Howe, and the Right Honourable George Gordon Noel Lord Byron, in right of the Right Honourable Anne Isabella Noel Lady Byron, his Wife, are Lords of the Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston aforesaid, and entitled to the Soil of all the Commons and Waste Lands within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston: And whereas the said Richard William Penn Earl Howe is Patron of and entitled to the perpetual Advowson and Right of Presentation of and to the Rectory of the Parish Church of Congerston otherwise Congeston aforesaid; and the Reverend John Roby Clerk is the present Rector thereof, and in right of the said Rectory is entitled to certain Glebe Lands, and to certain Great or Rectorial Tithes arising and issuing from and out of [Private.'] 4 q certain

338

4° GEORGII IV. Cap. 23.

certain Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, and to all the Small and Vicarial Tithes, Ecclesiastical Dues, and Payments of what Nature or Kind soever to the said Rectory and Parish Church belonging : And whereas the King’s most Excellent Majesty, in Right of His Crown, is Patron ot and entitled to the perpetual Advowson and Right of Presentation of and to the Rectory and Parish Church of Nelson otherwise Nailstone, in the said County of Leicester; and the Reverend Robert Crockett Clerk is the present Rector thereof, and in right of the said Rectory is entitled to certain Great or Rectorial Tithes arising and issuing from and out of certain Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, and to all the Small and Vicarial Tithes, Ecclesiastical Dues, and Payments of what Nature or Kind soever to the said last-mentioned Rectory and Parish Church belonging : And whereas Elizabeth Frances Pochin Widow is Patron of and entitled to the perpetual Advowson and Right of Presentation of and to the Rectory and Parish Church of Market Bosworth in the said County of Leicester; and the Reverend Thomas Wright Clerk is the present Rector thereof, and in right of the said Rectory is entitled to certain Great or Rectorial Tithes arising and issuing from and out of certain Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, and to all the Small and Vicarial Tithes, Ecclesiastical Dues, and Payments of what Nature or Kind soever to the said last-mentioned Rectory and Parish Church belonging : And whereas Henry Edward Hall Esquire is entitled to the Right of Presentation to the Vicarage of Shaxton otherwise Shackston otherwise Shackerston, in the said County of Leicester, subject to a Grant thereof made by him to George Greenway of Attleborough Hall, in the County of Warwick, Esquire, for a Term of Twenty-one Years, commencing from the Fifth Day of April One thousand eight hundred and eighteen, if the said Henry Edward Hall shall so long live; and the Reverend Tfrilliam Whitmore Greenway Clerk is the present Vicar thereof, and in right of the said Vicarage is entitled to certain Great or Rectorial Tithes arising and issuing from and out of certain Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Con-

feston, and to all the Small and Vicarial Tithes, Ecclesiastical Dues, and ^yments of what Nature or Kind soever to the said Vicarage belonging : And whereas the said Richard William Penn Earl Howe and divers other Persons respectively are Owners and Proprietors of the said Open and Common Fields, Meadows and Pastures, and of the several Messuages and other Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, and in respect thereof, or of some Part or Parts thereof, are or claim to be entitled to certain Rights of Common and other Commonable Rights and Interests ii^, over, and upon the same Commons and Waste Lands: And whereas an Act was passed in the Forty-first Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, 41G.3.C. 109. intituled An Act for consolidating in One Act certain Provisions usually inserted in Acts of Inclosure; and for facilitating the Mode of proving the several Facts usually required on the passing of such Acts: And whereas another Act was passed in the First and Second Years of the Reign of 1&2G.4.C. 23. Present Majesty King George the Fourth, intituled An Act to amend the Law respecting the inclosing of Open Fields, Pastures, Moors, Commons, and Waste Lands, in England : And whereas the said Lands in the said Open

5 and

4° GEORGII IV. 23. 339

and Common Fields, Meadows and Pastures, lie intermixed and dispersed in small Parcels, and are inconveniently situate for the Occupation thereof, and the same, as well as the said Commons and Waste Lands, in their present State, are incapable of any considerable Improvement, and it would be advantageous if the whole thereof were divided and allotted unto and amongst the several Proprietors thereof, and Persons interested therein, and such Allotments inclosed; and it would also be advantageous to all the Parties interested therein, if all and every the Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Conversion otherwise Congeston were exonerated and discharged from Tithes; but the said beneficial Objects cannot be effected without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That all and every the Open and Common Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, shall be divided, allotted, and inclosed in the Manner and according to the Orders, Provisions, and Directions herein-after mentioned, and also with, under, and subject to the Powers, Regulations, and Directions contained in the said recited Acts, except where the same are varied, altered, or otherwise provided for by this Act; and that John Farmer of Barton in Commis-the Beans, in the said County of Leicester, Gentleman, shall be and he is si°ner-hereby appointed the sole Commissioner for dividing, allotting, and inclosing the said Open and Common Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons, and Waste Lands, and for carrying this Act into Execution.

II. And be it further enacted, That if the said John Farmer, or any other Appointment Commissioner to be appointed in his Stead as herein-after mentioned, figure shall die, refuse or neglect to act, or become incapable of acting, before loners, the Powers hereby vested in him shall be executed, then and so often as any of the said Events shall occur, a public Meeting of the several Persons who for the Time being shall respectively be interested in the Lands and Grounds so intended to be divided and allotted as aforesaid, shall be called by any Two or more of such Persons, and be held as soon as conveniently may be after such Commissioner shall die, refuse or neglect to act, or become incapable of acting, and of which Meeting at least Fourteen Days previous Notice shall be given, in like Manner as other Notices of Meetings or Attendances are hereby directed to be given; and the Proprietors then and there assembled, or the major Part of them in Value,

(such Value to be ascertained by the Land Tax Assessment), or their respective Agents or Solicitors, duly authorized by Writing under the Hands of the respective Proprietors, shall and may nominate, elect, and appoint some other Person (not interested in the said Division and Allotment) to be aCommissioner in the Room or Stead of the said John Farmer, or such other Commissioner so dying, refusing, or neglecting to act, or becoming incapable of acting as aforesaid, and the Person so to be elected and appointed Commissioner shall be invested with and have the same Powers and Authorities in all respects to act in the Execution of this Act as if he had been originally nominated and appointed the Commissioner in and by this Act.

Power to enter Lands for the Purpose of surveying.

4° GEORGII IV. Cap.23.

III. And be it further enacted, That Thomas Miles of Keykam in the County of Leicester, Land Surveyor, shall be and he is hereby appointed the Surveyor for the Purposes of this Act and the said recited Acts, subject to the Direction and Controul of the said Commissioner; and in case of the Death, Incapacity, Neglect, or Refusal of the said Thomas Miles to act, then and in any such Case the said Commissioner shall appoint such other Person or Persons (not interested in the said Division and Inclosure) as he shall think proper, to be Surveyor for the Purposes aforesaid in his Stead, as often as occasion shall require: Provided always, that the said Thomas Miles, or any other Person or Persons so to be appointed Surveyors as aforesaid, before he or they shall proceed to act as such Surveyor, shall take and subscribe the Oath following; which Oath it shall be lawful for the Commissioner for the Time being to administer:

c T do swear [or, being one of the People called Quakers,

c A do solemnly affirm], That I will faithfully, impartially, and 4 honestly, according to the best of my Skill and Ability, execute and c Perform the several Trusts, Powers, and Authorities vested and reposed ‘ in me as Surveyor by virtue of an Act passed in the Fourth Year 6 of the Reign of King George the Fourth, intituled [here insert the c Title of this Act], according to Equity and good Conscience, and without Favour or Affection, Prejudice or Partiality, to any Person or Persons ‘ whomsoever. So help me GOD.*

IV. And be it further enacted, That the Commissioner for the Time being shall be allowed and paid the Sum of Three Guineas, and no more, for every Day which he shall travel or be employed, and actually attend in any Business relating to the Execution of the Powers and Authorities hereby in him reposed, which Sum shall include all his Expences*; but the said Commissioner shall not be paid the said Allowance for more than Two Days in respect of going to and returning from the Place of his Attendance or Sitting; and that the said Thomas Miles, and the Surveyor to be appointed by the said Commissioner, shall be paid such Sum or Sums of Money for his Pains, Trouble, Expences, and Attendances on the said Commissioner in the Execution of this Act, as the Commissioner shall think just and reasonable.

V. And be it further enacted, That for the Purpose of surveying and valuing all the Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, and for other the Purposes of this or the said recited Acts, it shall be lawful for the Commissioner and Surveyor, or either of them respectively, and for their respective Assistants and Servants, at any Time or Times whatsoever, until such Division shall be completed, and the Award of the Commissioner shall be executed, to enter into and upon all and every or any Part and Parts of the Lands and Grounds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, and to do or cause to be done any Act or Thing necessary for carrying this and the said recited Acts into Execution, without being liable to any Action or Suit.

4° GEORGII ^IV. Cap.23.

VI. And be it further enacted, That the said Commissioner shall and he is hereby empowered to appoint a Clerk to assist him in the Execution of this Act and the said recited Acts, and to remove such Clerk and appoint another in his Stead, and to pay to such Clerk all such fair and

1 reasonable Charges and Disbursements as to him the said Commissioner shall seem right and proper.

VII. And be it further enacted, That all Meetings and Attendances of the said Commissioner for the Execution of this Act, at which the Presence of any of the Owners or Proprietors of the said Lands and Grounds hereby directed to be divided, allotted, and inclosed, or of any Person or Persons interested therein, shall be necessary or required, shall be held within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, or within the Distance of Eight Miles therefrom; and that the Commissioner for the Time being shall and he is hereby required to give or cause to be given public Notice, by Advertisement in some Newspaper published or generally circulated in the said County of Leicester, and also by Writing under the Hand of the Clerk to be by him employed as aforesaid, to be affixed on the principal outer Door of the Parish Church of Congerston otherwise Congeston aforesaid, of the Time and Place of the first and every subsequent Meeting or Attendance, at least Ten Days previously thereto (Meetings and Attendances by Adjournment only excepted); and that all other Notices necessary or requisite to be given by the said Commissioner shall be given in like Manner as the Notices of the said Meetings and Attendances are herein-before directed to be given; and that the Commissioner, Clerk, and Surveyor, and each and every Proprietor attending any such Meeting, shall pay his own Expences.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That all Orders and Proceedings

of the said Commissioner shall be entered in a Book or Books to be provided for that Purpose, and shall be signed by the Commissioner; and such Book, and the Entries therein of such Orders respectively, shall and may be read in Evidence in all Suits or Actions concerning any thing done in or about the Execution of this Act.

IX. X. And be it further enacted, That in case the Commissioner for the Time being shall, upon the Hearing and Determination of any Claim or Claims, Objection or Objections to be delivered to him in pursuance of this or the said first recited Act, see Cause to award any Costs, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Commissioner, and he is hereby empowered, upon Application made to him for that Purpose, to settle, assess, and award such Costs and Charges as he shall think reasonable, to be paid to the Party or Parties in whose Favour any Determination of the said Commissioner shall be made, by the Person or Persons, Body or Bodies Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, whose Claim or Claims, Objection or Objections, shall be thereby disallowed or overruled; and in case the Person or Persons, Body or Bodies Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, who shall be liable to pay such Costs and Charges, shall neglect or refuse to pay the same on Demand, then and in such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Commissioner, and he is hereby authorized and required, by Warrant under his Hand and Seal, directed to any Person whomsoever, to cause such Costs and Charges to be levied by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Person or Persons, Body or Bodies Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate so neglecting or refusing to pay the same, rendering the Overplus, (if any) upon Demand, to the Person or Persons, Body or Bodies Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, whose Goods and Chattels shall have been so distrained and sold, after deducting the Costs and Charges attending such Distress and Sale.

Persons dissatisfied may try their Rights at Law:

XIV. And be it further enacted, That all Encroachments and Inclosures which have been made at any Time or Times within the Space of Twenty Years previous to the passing of this Act, from, in, or upon the said Open and Common Fields, Meadows, Pastures, Commons and Waste Lands, within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, shall be deemed and considered to be Part of the Lands to be divided and allotted by virtue of this Act; and in case any Dispute or Difference shall arise touching any such Encroachments or Inclosures, or the Extent thereof, such Dispute shall be determined by the said Commissioner.

XV. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Commissioner, at any Time when he in his Judgment shall think it convenient and proper, by Notice for that Purpose under his Hand, to be affixed on the principal outer Door of the Parish Church of Congerston otherwise Congeston aforesaid, on some Sunday previous to Divine Service, to order the Rights of Common in, upon, and over the Lands and Grounds hereby directed to be divided, allotted, and inclosed, or any of them, to be extinguished, either in the Whole or in Part, or to be suspended; and from and after the Time or Times to be mentioned in and appointed by any such Notice, all such Rights of Common as shall thereby be directed to be extinguished or suspended, shall be extinguished or suspended.

according to and as shall be expressed in and directed by such Notice; and if, during such Suspension, or after such Extinguishment of such Rights of Common, any of the said Proprietors or Occupiers shall permit his, her, or their Cattle or Sheep to go, depasture, or feed in any of the said Lands or Grounds over which such Rights of Common shall be extinguished or suspended, then it shall be lawful for any other of the said Proprietors or Occupiers to distrain such Cattle or Sheep, being upon such Lands or Grounds contrary to such Notice, and to impound the same, until such Person or Persons so offending shall pay to the Person or Persons so distraining any Sum not exceeding Ten Shillings for each Head of Cattle, and Five Shillings for each Sheep so distrained, as the said Commissioner shall direct; and in case the same, with all Costs, Charges, and Expences, shall not be paid before the next Sitting of the said Commissioner after such impounding, the said Commissioner is hereby authorized and empowered, upon Proof of such Offence or Offences having been committed, and Non-payment of the Penalty or Penalties incurred, to cause the Cattle or Sheep so distrained, or such of them as he shall think fit, to be sold for raising and paying the Penalty or Penalties so incurred as aforesaid, together with the Costs and Charges attending every such Distress and Sale, rendering the Overplus (if any) upon Demand, to the Owner or Owners of such Cattle or ^eeP* jhfitnsW (jhobbs'l

XXIX. XXXIV. And be it further enacted, That the several and respective For fencing Allotments to be made in the said several Open Fields, Meadows, Pas- Allotment*, tures, Commons, and Waste Lands, within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, after the Division thereof, shall within Six Calendar Months, to be computed from the signing and sealing the Award of the said Commissioner, or within any shorter Space of Time to be appointed by the said Commissioner, be inclosed, and the Fences thereof composed of and planted with young Quicksets, and such Fences, where the same shall adjoin upon any public or private Road or Way, and in such other Place or Places as the said Commissioner shall think fit, shall be guarded with good and substantial Posts and Rails, or otherwise, and with such Ditches on either or each Side thereof as the said Commissioner shall direct and appoint, and also with good and substantial Gates and Stiles to be made, where necessary, in the said Fences; all which said Fences shall be so planted and guarded as aforesaid, and the Gates and Stiles made by and at the proper Costs and Charges of the respective Persons to whom the same shall be respectively allotted, in such Manner, Shares, and Proportions as the said Commissioner shall in and by his said Award order and direct.

XXXVI. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Commissioner to set out, allot, and award any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments whatsoever, within the said Parishes respectively, in lieu of and in Exchange for any other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments whatsoever within the said Parishes respectively, or within any adjoining Parish, Township, or Place, provided that all such Exchanges be ascertained, specified, and declared in and by the Award of the said Commissioner, and be made with the Consent of the Owner or Owners or Proprietor or Proprietors of the Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments which shall be so exchanged, whether such Owner or Owners or Proprietor or Proprietors shall be a Body or Bodies Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, or a Tenant or Tenants in Fee Simple, or for Life, or in Fee Tail General or Special, or by the Curtesy of England, or for a Life or Lives, or for Years determinable on a Life or Lives, by and with the Consent of the Lessor or Lessors of any Leasehold Hereditaments, but not otherwise, or with the Consent of the Guardians, Trustees, Feoffees for Charitable or other Uses, Husbands, Committees, or Attornies of or for such Owners or Proprietors, who at the Time of making such Exchange or Exchanges shall be respectively Infants, Femes Covert, Lunatics, or under any other legal Disability, or who shall be beyond the Seas, or otherwise disabled to act for themselves, himself, or herself, (such Consents to be testified in Writing under the Common Seal of every such Body Politic, Corporate, or Collegiate, and under the Hands of the other consenting Parties respectively); and all and every such Exchange and Exchanges so to be made shall be good, valid, and effectual in the Law to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever: Provided nevertheless, that no such Exchange shall be made of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, held in right of any Church, Chapel, or other Ecclesiastical Benefice, without the Consent, testified as aforesaid, of the Patron thereof, and of the Bishop of the Diocese in which such Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments so to be exchanged shall lie and be situate.

XXXVII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That all Costs, Charges, and Expences attending the making of any Sales, Exchanges, or Partitions to be made by virtue of this or the said first recited Act, shall be paid, borne, and defrayed by the several Persons making such Sales, Exchanges, and Partitions, in such Manner, Shares, and Proportions as the said Commissioner shall by any Writing under his Hand direct.

XLI. And be it further enacted, That in the meantime and until such Division and Allotment shall be made as aforesaid, all Tillage and other Lands lying in the said several Open Common Fields and other Common-able Lauds within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, shall be stocked with such Cattle, and shall be cropped and sown with such Sorts of Corn, Grain, and Seeds, and in such Proportions, and shall be kept, ordered, and continued in such Course of Husbandry, as the said Commissioner shall by Writing under his Hand in that Behalf order, direct, and appoint; any Usage or Custom to the contrary notwithstanding.

XLV. And be it further enacted, That all the Costs, Charges, and Expences of obtaining this Act, and all Proceedings which have been taken relative or preparatory thereto, and also all Charges and Expences which may be incurred in carrying this Act into Execution, and of making and completing the Public Roads to be set out, and of preparing and inrolling the Award of the said Commissioner, or so much of such Costs, Charges, and Expences as the Money arising from the Sale of such Part or Parts of the said Commons and Waste Lands as shall be sold under and by virtue of the Directions herein-before contained shall not be sufficient to defray, shall be borne, made up, and paid by all the Owners and Proprietors of, or Persons having Rights or Interests in the Lands or Grounds hereby directed to be divided, allotted, inclosed, and exonerated from Tithes, (except the Rectors and Vicar of the said Rectories and Vicarage for the Time being, and also except the Surveyor or Surveyors of the Highways within the said Manor of Congerston otherwise Congeston, in respect of the Allotment or Allotments to be made to him or them in Trust as aforesaid), in proportion to the Value of their several and respective Rights, Shares, and Interests therein, and the Amount thereof shall be settled, ascertained, and adjusted by the said Commissioner, and shall be paid at such Time and Place, or Times and Places, and to such Person or Persons as the said Commissioner shall appoint; and the said Commissioner shall and he is hereby authorized and required accordingly to make One or more Rate or Rates, or Assessment or Assessments thereof respectively under his Hand, and the same Rate or Rates, Assessment or Assessments so made and signed, shall be binding and conclusive on all Parties thereby charged and made liable, and their several and respective Executors and Administrators; and in case any Person or Persons shall refuse or neglect to pay his, her, or their Share or Proportion of such Rate or Rates, Assessment or Assessments as aforesaid, within such Time or Times, and to such Person or Persons, and at such Place or Places as the said Commissioner shall appoint, then and in such Case the said Commissioner shall cause the same to be levied and recovered in manner directed by the said first recited Act.

Provided also, and be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful for any such Proprietor or Proprietors to charge, and they are hereby restrained and prevented from charging the several Lands and Grounds which shall be allotted to them respectively, or any Part or Parts thereof, with any Sum or Sums of Money whatsoever, for the Purpose of paying and defraying any such Costs, Charges, and Expences aforesaid, under and by virtue of the first herein-before recited Act.

L. And be it further enacted, That Once at least in each and every Year during the Execution of this Act (such Year to be computed from the passing of this Act), the said Commissioner shall and he is hereby required to make a true and just Statement or Account of all Sums of Money by him received and expended, or due to him for his own Trouble and Expences in the Execution of this Act; and such Statement or Account when so made, together with the Vouchers relating thereto, shall be laid before One of His Majesty's Justices of the Peace in and for the County of Leicester (not interested in the Inclosure), to be by him examined and balanced, and such Balance shall be by such Justice stated in the Book of Accounts to be kept in the Office of the Clerk of the said Commissioner; and no Charge or Item in such Accounts shall be binding on the Parties concerned, or valid in Law, unless the same shall have been allowed by such Justice.

LI. And be it further enacted, That the Commissioner shall and he is hereby required, within Three Years from the passing of this Act, unless prevented by Law Suits or Appeals, to form and draw up, or cause to be formed and drawn up, pursuant to the Directions of the said first recited Act, an Award which shall contain and comprise such Matters and Things required by the said recited Act as relate to or in anywise concern the . Execution of this and the said recited Acts, and the Division, Allotment, and Inclosure hereby authorized; which said Award, when inrolled as directed by the said first recited Act, shall be deposited and kept in a Box in the Parish Church of Congerston otherwise Congeston aforesaid, under the Care of the Churchwardens of the said Parish for the Time being; and it shall and may be lawful to and for the several and respective Owners and Proprietors, or their respective Counsel, Attornies, Solicitors, or Agents, from Time to Time and at all Times to have Access thereto, (paying for every Inspection the Sum of One Shilling), and to take Copies, Abstracts, or Extracts thereof or therefrom; and the said Churchwardens for the Time being are required to permit or suffer the same to be done from Time to Time accordingly, but the Award shall not be taken out of or removed from the said Parish Church aforesaid by any Person or Persons, or on any Pretence whatsoever.

4° GEORGII IV. Cap.2S. 361

LII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if any Person Power of or Persons shall think himself, herself, or themselves aggrieved by any Appeal, thing done in pursuance of this or the said recited Acts, (except where the Orders, Determinations, or Proceedings of the said Commissioner are hereby or by the said recited Acts declared to be final and conclusive, and except as to such Claims, Matters, and Things as are herein-before directed or authorized to be tried, settled, or determined by the Verdict of a Jury), then and in every such Case he, she, or they may appeal to the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace which shall be held in and for the said County of Leicester within Four Calendar Months next after the Cause of Complaint shall have arisen, on giving Fourteen Days Notice of such Appeal, and of the Matter thereof, to the Respondent or Respondents; and the Justices in their said Quarter Sessions, on Proof of due Notice of the said Appeal, and the Matter and Cause thereof, are hereby required to hear and determine the same, and to make such Orders therein and award such Costs as to them shall seem reasonable, and by their Order or Warrant to levy the Costs which shall be so awarded by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Party or Parties or Person or Persons liable to pay the same, rendering the Overplus (if any) to the Owner or Owners of such Goods and Chattels, after deducting the Costs and Charges of such Distress and Sale; which Determination of the said Justices shall be final, binding, and conclusive on all Parties concerned, and shall not be removed or removable, by Certiorari or otherwise, into any of His Majesty's Courts of Record at Westminster or otherwise.

LIII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That nothing in this Saving Act contained shall extend, or be construed or adjudged to extinguish, Rights of the defeat, release,.lessen, or prejudice the Right, Title, or Interest of the ^ar^rof the Lord or Lords, Lady or Ladies of the said Manor, of, in, or to the Seigniories, Rights, Royalties, Franchises, Jurisdictions, Rents, Services,

Liberties, Privileges, Powers, and Authorities, appendant, incident, or of Right belonging to the said Manor, or to the Lord or Lords, Lady or Ladies of the said Manor for the Time being, but that they respectively shall have, hold, use, exercise, take, and enjoy the Seigniories, Rights,

Royalties, Franchises, Jurisdictions, Rents, Services, Powers, Authorities,

Liberties, and Privileges whatsoever to the said Manor belonging or incident, appendant or appurtenant, in as full, ample, and beneficial a Manner, to all Intents and Purposes, as they respectively have before held, exercised, and enjoyed, or might or could have held, exercised, and enjoyed the same, in case this Act had not been passed.

LIV. Saving always to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs General and Successors, and to all and every other Person and Persons, Bodies Sav,ng-Politic and Corporate, his, her, and their Heirs, Successors, Executors and Administrators, all such Estate, Right, Title, and Interest, (other than such as are expressly barred or meant and intended to be barred by this Act), as they, every, or any of them had and enjoyed of, in, to or in respect of the said Lands and Grounds hereby directed to be divided, allotted, and inclosed, previous to the passing of this Act, or could or might have had and enjoyed in case the same had not been passed.

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 24.

An Act for vesting Part of the Estates devised by the Will of Thomas Viscount Wentworth in Trustees, upon Trust to sell the same to the Right Honourable Richard William Penn Earl Howe, and to apply the Money arising from the Sale thereof in the Purchase of other Estates in the Counties of Leicester and Warwick, or one of them, to be settled to the subsisting Uses of the said Will.

[4th July 1823.]

WHEREAS the Right Honourable Thomas Viscount Wentworth and Baron Wentworth of Nettlestead, did, in such Manner as the Law requires for the Validity of Devises of Freehold Estates, duly sign and publish his last Will and Testament in Writing, bearing Date the Eighth Day of June One thousand eight hundred and five, whereby he gave and devised all and singular his Manors, Messuages, Lands, Tenements, Rectories, Advowsons, Tithes, Rents and other Hereditaments whatsoever, situate in the several Counties of Leicester and Warwick, to which, under the Settlement made previous to his Marriage with his Wife Mary, late Dowager Countess Ligonier, he was entitled in Fee Simple in Reversion expectant on the Limitations therein contained, to his Sons successively in Tail Male, subject to the Term for Years, and Charges thereby created, and to the Mortgages or Incumbrances therein mentioned or recited; and also all other his Manors, Mes-[Private,'] 4 % suages,

VIII. And be it further enacted, That the said Purchase Money which shall be paid into the Bank of England under the Directions of this Act, shall, in the meantime and until the same Money shall be invested in the Purchase of Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments as aforesaid, be laid out by the said Accountant General, under the Directions of the said Court of Chancery, to be obtained as herein-after is mentioned, in the Purchase of Navy, or Victualling, or Transport, or Exchequer Bills, and the Interest arising from the Money so laid out in Navy, or Victualling, or Transport, or Exchequer Bills, and the Money received for the same, should they or any of them be paid off by Government, be laid out in the Name of the said Accountant General in the Purchase of other Navy, or Victualling, or Transport, or Exchequer Bills, and so from Time to Time as occasion shall require; provided that it shall and may be lawful for the said Court to make such General Order or Orders, or Special Order or Orders, if necessary, that whenever the Exchequer Bills of the Date of those in the Hands of the said Accountant General shall be in course of Payment by Government, and new Exchequer Bills shall be issued, such new Exchequer Bills may be received for those in Exchange, which are so in the course of Payment, as shall be effectual for enabling such Receipt in Exchange, and that in that Event the Interest of the old Bills shall be laid out as before directed with respect to the Interest on the Bills which are paid off, and all such Navy, and Victualling, and Transport and Exchequer Bills, whether purchased or exchanged, shall be deposited in the Bank of England, in the Name of the said Accountant General, and shall remain there until a proper Purchase or proper Purchases shall be found and approved in the Manner directed by this Act, and until the same shall, under the Direction of the said Court, to be obtained as herein-after is mentioned, be ordered to be sold by the Accountant General for completing such Purchases; and if the Money arising by the Sale of such Navy, or Victualling, or Transport or Exchequer Bills, shall exceed the Amount of the whole Purchase Money so laid out as aforesaid, then, and in such Case only, the Surplus which shall remain shall be paid to such Person or Persons respectively as would have been entitled to receive the Rents and Profits of the Lands directed to be purchased pursuant to this Act, or to the Personal Representatives of such Person or Persons.

X. And be it further enacted, That if the said Morton Lord Henley and Power to Charles Montolieu Burges, or either of them, or any Trustees or Trustee appoint new to be appointed for the Purposes of this Act, as herein-after is mentioned, Trustees* or their or any or either of their Heirs or Assigns, shall happen to die or be desirous of being discharged of and from, or refuse or decline or become incapable to act in the Trusts hereby created before the same shall be performed, then and in such Case, and so often as it shall so

happen, it shall be lawful for the said Court of Chancery, in a summary

Way, upon the Petition of the Person or Persons who for the Time being shall be entitled to the Rents, Issues, and Profits of the Hereditaments and Premises to be purchased and settled as aforesaid, or to have the same paid for her separate Use, if such Person shall have attained his or her Age of Twenty-one Years, but if such Person shall be under that Age, then of his or her Guardian or Guardians during his or her Minority or respective Minorities, from Time to Time to nominate and appoint any other Person or Persons, to be a Trustee or Trustees in the Stead or Place of the Trustee or Trustees so dying or desirous to be discharged, or refusing, declining, or becoming incapable to act as aforesaid, and when and so often as any Trustee or Trustees shall have been nominated and appointed in Manner aforesaid, all the Trust Estates shall be vested in him jointly with the surviving or continuing Trustees or Trustee, or solely as’occasion shall require, upon the same Trusts as are herein-before declared of and concerning the same Trust Estates, or such of them as shall or may be then subsisting and capable of taking Effect, and every such new Trustee shall have the same Powers and Authorities as the Trustee in whose Room he shall be substituted.

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 25.

An Act to amend an Act passed in the Fifty-eighth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act for vesting certain Pieces or Parcels of Land and other Hereditaments, belonging to Sidney Sussex College in the University of Cambridge, in Trustees for Sale, with Powers to lease on Fines, and for applying the Purchase Monies, and Monies to arise from Fines, in manner therein mentioned.

[4th July 1823.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Fifty-eighth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, intituled An Act for vesting certain Pieces or Parcels of Land and 58G*3.c,39. other Hereditaments, belonging to Sidney Sussex College in the University of Cambridge, in Trustees for Sale, with Powers to lease on Fines, and for applying the Purchase Monies, and Monies to arise from Fines, in manner therein mentioned; and thereby after reciting amongst other Things that Samuel Taylor, late of Dudley in the County of Worcester, Bachelor of Civil Law, duly made and published his last Will and Testament in Writing, bearing Date the Tenth Day of September One thousand seven hundred and twenty-six, executed and attested in such Manner as is by Law required for passing Freehold Estates, and thereby gave and devised I Private.'] 5 C to

4§ GEORGII IVi C^>.25.

to the Master and Fellows of Sidney Sussex College in the University of Cambridge, and to their Heirs and Successors for ever, certain ^Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments in his said Will particularly described, situate^ lying, and being in the Manor of Dudley in the County of Worcester, and in Oaken, otherwise Qking, and at Tipton Green in the County of Stafford, to have and to hold the same, with the Appurtenances, unto the said Master and Fellows of Sidney Sussex College, their Heirs and Successors for ever, upon the Trusts and for the Intents and Purposes therein mentioned; and also reciting a Decree of the Court of Chancery touching and concerning the same, it was enacted, that all and singular the Mines, Veins, and Seams of Coal, Limestone, Ironstone, and other Minerals lying under certain Hereditaments devised by the said Will, and particularly described in the said Act and in a Schedule thereto, should be vested in and settled upon John Minet Henniker of Stratford Green in the County of Essex, Esquire, and John Chafy of Walcot Place, in the Parish of Lambeth in the County of Surrey, Esquire, their Heirs and Assigns, to the Use of them the said John Minet Henniker and John Chafy, their Heirs and Assigns for ever, absolutely freed, discharged, acquitted, exempted, and exonerated of and from all and every the Uses, Trusts, Estates, Powers, Provisoes, and Limitations in and by the said Will of the said Testator, and the said Decree, or either of them, limited, expressed, or declared of or concerning the same, but nevertheless upon the several Trusts, and to and for the several Ends, Intents, and Purposes thereinafter expressed and declared of and concerning the same; (that is to say), upon Trust, that they the said John Minet Henniker and John Chafy, or the Survivor of them, or the Heirs or Assigns of such Survivor should, with all convenient Speed, with the Consent and Approbation of the Master, Fellows, and Scholars for the Time being of the said College, testified by any Instrument in Writing under the Seal of the said College, sell and dispose of the said Mines, Veins, and Seams of Coal, Limestone, Iron-stone, and other Minerals lying under the said Pieces or Parcels of Land and other Hereditaments so thereby vested in them as aforesaid, by public Auction or private Contract, and together or in Parcels, with full Power and Authority to dig, try for, win, work, and get the said Coal, Limestone, Ironstone, and other Minerals thereby made saleable, and to erect such Steam Engines and other Buildings, and make such Roads and Ways, and do such other Acts as might be necessary on the said Pieces or Parcels of Land, unto any Person or Persons whomsoever, for the best Price or Prices that could be reasonably had or gotten for the same; and on Payment of the Purchase Money, for which the same should be so respectively sold, into the Bank of England as therein-after mentioned, should convey and assure the same Mines, Veins, and Seams under the said Pieces or Parcels of Land and other Hereditaments, or such Part thereof as should be so sold as aforesaid, and the Fee Simple and Inheritance and absolute Property of and in the same and every Part thereof respectively, with the Appurtenances, unto and to the Use of the Purchaser or Purchasers thereof, and his, her, or their Heirs and Assigns, or as he, she, or they should direct or appoint, freed, discharged, acquitted, exempted, and exonerated as aforesaid : Provided always, and it was thereby further enacted, that notwithstanding any thing therein-before contained to the contrary, it should and might be lawful to and for the said John Minet Henniker and John Chafy, or the Survivor of them, or the Heirs or Assigns of such Survivor, and they and he were and was thereby directed, at the

to that Court in a summary Way, by or on Behalf of the Master, Fellows, and Scholars for the Time being of the said College, to order and direct the Monies so to be paid into the Bank of England as after Payment of the Costs, Charges, and Expences therein-after mentioned, and also after Payment of the Sum of Four thousand Pounds to the Master, Fellows, and Scholars of the said College, for the Purpose likewise thereinafter mentioned, to be laid out in the Purchase of Freehold Manors, Messuages, Farms, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments of an Estate of Inheritance in Fee Simple in Possession, free from Incumbrances, except Quit-rents and Leases at Rack-rent; and that all and singular the said Manors, Messuages, Farms, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments which should be so purchased as aforesaid, should be thereupon immediately settled, conveyed, and assured unto and to the Use of the said Master, Fellows, and Scholars for the Time being, and their Successors; and that the Master, Fellows, and Scholars for the Time being of the said College should stand and be seised and possessed of the said Manors, Messuages, Farms, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments upon Trust, to pay Yearly to the Mathematical Lecturer in the said College for the Time being, not exceeding the Sum of Thirty Pounds, as a Compensation for the Injury done to the Soil of the said Lands by working the said Mines, Veins, and Seams, and to appropriate the Surplus of the clear annual Rents, Issues, and Profits thereof unto and among such Persons, being Graduates or Under Graduates of the University of Cambridge, as should appear in the Judgment of the said Master and Fellows, or the major Part of them at that Time resident in the said College, to be the best Proficients in Mathematical Learning; and it was provided, that no Person should receive any Part of the said Rents and Profits until he should have entered into and becorrie a Member of the said College, and that no Part of the said Rents

III. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Court of Chancery from Time to Time, upon Petition in a summary Way, to be preferred by the said Master, Fellows, and Scholars, to order and direct that the Costs, Charges, and Expences of applying for and obtaining and passing this Act, and all the Costs, Charges, and Expences attending or relating to the several Applications already made and to be made to the said Court respecting the Matters aforesaid, and the Costs incurred in taking the said Monies out of the Bank, or otherwise in carrying any of the Purposes of this Act into Execution, shall be paid and satisfied out of the Monies which have been or which shall at any Time hereafter be paid into the Bank pursuant to the Directions of the herein-before recited Act passed in the Fifty-eighth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Third, or out of the Monies arising by Sale of any Navy, Victualling, Transport, or Exchequer Bills which may be or shall have been purchased with such Monies, or with any Part thereof, such Costs, Charges, and Expences being first taxed and settled by One of the Masters of the said Court, in pursuance of an Order or Orders which the said Court is hereby authorized to make.

and it was enacted, that in case any such Lease to be granted with the Concurrence of any original Lessee or Lessees, or his or their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns as aforesaid, should be avoided, under or by virtue or means of the Power of Re-entry which should be reserved as aforesaid, or any other Power of Re-entry to be inserted in any such Lease, then and in that Case, and notwithstanding the Avoidance of any such Lease, the Person or Persons who for the Time being should be entitled to that Portion of the said Rent which should be reserved to such Lessee or Lessees, his, her, or their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, should continue entitled to such Portion of Rent or Rents for the Residue of the Term granted by the avoided Lease, or during such Part of the said Term as should be agreed on for the Continuance of such Portion of the said Rent or Rents in Manner aforesaid, so nevertheless that in case the Rents and Profits which should be actually received by or payable to the said Lord Archbishop, or his Successors, from or in respect of any Lands, Grounds, Houses, Buildings, or Hereditaments, which should be comprised in any Lease so avoided as aforesaid, should be less in Amount than the Rent which should have been reserved by such avoided Lease, then and in such Case the original Lessee or Lessees, his, her, or their Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, should not be entitled to have, receive, or demand of or from the said Lord Archbishop, or his Successors, or his or their Tenants or Lessees for the Time being, of the Lands or Grounds, Houses or Buildings, which should be comprized in such Lease, more than a rateable Share of the Rents or Profits which should be actually received by or payable to the said Lord Archbishop, his Successors or Assigns as aforesaid, proportionate to the Share of such Lessee or Lessees under the Rent reserved by such, avoided Lease $ and it was enacted, that

and also paying all Costs, Charges, and Expences incurred in recovering Possession of the said Premises in consequence of such Avoidance, and also upon the Terms of performing all such Covenants respecting the Building, Repairs, and Improvements of the Premises to be comprised in such new Lease, as ought to have been performed by the former Lessee or Lessees, his, her, or their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, and subject to the same Provisoes, Covenants, and Restrictions, as should be contained in such avoided Lease, so far as the same should be applicable j and it was further enacted, that no Lease which should be granted to any such Lessee or Lessees, his, her, or their Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, under the Provisions last therein-before contained, should be renewable under or by virtue of the same Provision, in case such Lease should become voidable and be voided by any Condition of Re-entry which should be contained therein; Cap. 27.

An Act for empowering the Judges of the Court of Session in Scotland to sell certain Parts of the Dominium directum or Superiority of the Entailed Estate of Park in the County of Banff, presently belonging to Thomas Gordon Esquire of Park, and to apply the Price to be obtained for the same in the Payment of the Debts affecting the said

Estate.

three, divided and apportioned amongst the said Lands and Barony, into Five several Lots or Portions, the Valuation of Four of which Lots or Por-; tions exceeds Four hundred Pounds Scots each, thus affording Four Freehold Qualifications: And whereas the Superiority or Dominium directum of the said Lands and Barony yields no Rents or Profits to the Heirs of 1 ailzie; but in respect of the before-recited Bond of Tailzie, and the Prohibitions and Limitations therein contained, these Purposes cannot be accomplished without the Aid and Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That it shall and may be lawful and competent to and for the Judges of the Court of Session in Scotland for the Time being, in either Division thereof, and they are hereby authorized and required, upon a Petition to be presented to the said Court, in either Division thereof, by Thomas Gordon now of Park, or the Heir of Entail for the Time being entitled to the said Entailed Estate of Park, or his or her Tutors or Curators if under the Age of Twenty-one Years; and after due Notice of such Petition being given to all concerned, in the Manner to be directed by the said Court, and hearing all Parties that may appear for their Interest, to inquire into and take an Account of the Debts of the said Sir James Gordon of Park, the Entailer, deceased, which were owing at the Time of his Death and are now due, and which affect or may be made to affect the said Estate, and how much of the said Debts remain unsatisfied; and having fixed and ascertained the Extent and Amount of such Debts, with the Interest due thereupon, by Interlocutors or Judgments, to order the Superiority or Dominium directum of the said Two Lots or Portions of the foresaid Lands and Barony, (or Freehold Qualifications), set forth in the said Second Schedule to this Act annexed, to be sold by Public Auction or Sale to the highest Offerer; and that in such Form and Manner as is requisite and necessary by the Law of Scotland, and for carrying into Execution the said Sales, the Judges of the said Court of Session, in either Division thereof, shall be and are hereby authorized and required to take Proofs of the Values of the Dominium directum of the said Two Lots or Portions of the said Entailed Estate (or Freehold Qualifications), and the several Sums of Money at which the same ought to be set up and exposed to public Auction and Sale to the highest Offerer, in the Way and Manner herein directed and provided, and for that Purpose with Powers to the said Judges to grant Warrant for publishing the said Auction and Sale, and to adjust the Conditions and Articles thereof, as to them the said Judges shall appear best calculated to answer the End in view; and to adjudge such Lots or Portions of the Dominium directum of the said Lands (or Freehold Qualifications) in such Form and Manner as is requisite and necessary by the Law of Scotland, to the several and respective Purchaser or Purchasers

thereof,

and with and under the whole Reservations, Powers, Faculties, Burdens, Provisions, Conditions, Restrictions, Limitations, Clauses irritant and others, contained in the said Deed of Entail, and all this without incurring any Irritancy or Forfeiture, any thing in the said Deed of Entail to the contrary notwithstanding.

III. And be it further enacted, That after the said Sale or Sales shall have been so made, and the Price or Prices paid or consigned as aforesaid, the said Court shall be and they are hereby empowered and required to direct and order the said Price or Prices so paid or consigned to be paid and applied in manner following; videlicet, in the first place, in paying and defraying the necessary Charges and Expences that may be incurred in and about applying for, obtaining, and passing this Act, and by and through the carrying the same into Execution, including the Expences of expeding the Deeds and Writings hereby required to be made and granted; the Costs and Charges of all Proceedings to be had in the Court of Session under this Act being taxed and ascertained according to the Practice of that Court; and in the next place, and after ascertaining the net Amount of the Debts and Claims attaching to or affecting the said Entailed Lands and Barony, in the Payment of such Debts and Claims; and the Creditor or Creditors receiving such Payment shall be obliged to execute such Receipts, Discharges, or Renunciations of his or her Debt, to the Extent of the Sums paid, as the said Court shall deem sufficient for fully and completely freeing, purging, and disencumbering the whole Lands, Barony, and others foresaid, and every Part and Portion thereof, and the said Thomas Gordon and the whole Heirs of Tailzie called to succeed thereto, of such Debt and Grounds and Warrants of the same, and Diligence and Execution raised thereon for ever; and such Receipts, Discharges, or Renunciations shall be duly recorded in the Books of Council and Session, and in the Register of Sasines or Reversions.

IV. Provided always, and be it enacted, That in case a Surplus shall remain of the Price or Prices of the said Dominium directum, Superiority, or Freehold Qualifications so to be sold, after defraying the Expences attendant upon this Act, and the carrying the same into Execution, and after Payment of the foresaid Debts and Claims, the Judges of the said Court of Session, in either Division thereof, are hereby empowered and required to direct and order that the said Surplus shall be laid out and employed in the Purchase of other Lands lying contiguous to or convenient for the said Entailed Lands and Estate, or as much so as may be, which shall be limited and settled to the same Series of Heirs, and under the like Provisions, Conditions, Restrictions, Limitations, Clauses irritant and others, as the said Lands and Barony of Park, by the Bond of Tailzie foresaid, now stand limited and settled; and in the meantime, and until the Money shall be so applied, to order and direct that the same shall remain in the Bank of Scotland, or Royal Bank of Scotland, or Bank of the British Linen Company of Scotland, subject to the Direction of the Court of Session, in either Division thereof, in the Name or Names of such Person or Persons as the said Court shall have appointed as aforesaid, who shall annually receive the highest Interest which can be got for the same; and which Interest shall be annually accumulated and added to the Principal Sum, so that they may carry Interest together, until a proper Opportunity shall occur for laying out the same in manner before

directed; and until, upon a Petition to be preferred to the said Court, in either Division thereof, in a summary Way by the said Thomas Gordon, or any Heir of Entail in Possession of the said Estate, or the Tutors or Curators of such Heir if under Twenty-one Years of Age, the Money shall be ordered to be paid by the Treasurer of the Bank of Scotland, or the Cashier of the Royal Bank of Scotland, or the Manager of the Bank of the British Linen Company, for such of the above Purposes as the said Court shall direct: Provided always, that if the Money arising by the Principal and accumulated Interest of such Sum or Sums shall exceed the Amount of the Purchase Money so paid into the said Bank of Scotland or Royal Bank of Scotland, or Bank of the British Linen Company of Scotland, then and in that Case only the Surplus which shall remain, after discharging the Expence of the Application to the Court, shall be paid to the Person or Persons who for the Time being would be entitled to receive the Rents and Profits of the Lands directed to be purchased, in case the same had been purchased pursuant to this Act, or to the Representatives of such Person or Persons.

V. Saving and reserving unto the King’s most Excellent Majesty, His General Heirs and Successors, and to all and every other Person and Persons, Saving. Bodies Politic and Corporate, and to all Legatees, Annuitants, or Creditors of the said deceased Sir James Gordon, who are or may be existing

and unpaid (excepting the said Thomas Gordon, and the Heirs of Tailzie entitled by virtue of the said before-recited Bond of Tailzie to succeed to and take the said Lands and Estate of Park), all such Estate, Right,

Title, Interest, Claim, and Demand of, in, and to, or out of all or any Part of the said Lands and Estate, or the Monies to accrue by the Sale of the Superiority or Dominium directum foresaid, according as they, any or either of them, have or might have, claim, challenge, or demand, in case this Act had never been made.

VI. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the Evidence several Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, duly authorized to Clause, print the Statutes of the United Kingdom; and a Copy thereof so printed

by any of them shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges,

Justices, and others.

ANNO QUARTO

GEORGII IV. REGIS.

Cap. 28.

An Act for changing the Site of the Hospital at Sheffield in the County of York, founded by the Right Honourable Gilbert Earl of Shrewsbury; and for the better Regulation of the Affairs of that Charity. [lOthi 1823.]

HERE AS by an Act passed in the Eleventh Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the First> intituled An Act for vesting in Trustees several Lands, Tenements, and Heredita-?nentsy in the Counties of York and Derby, for the Maintenance of the poor Persons in the Hospital of Gilbert Earl of Shrewsbury, long since deceased, situate at Sheffield in the said County of Y ork, and for enlarging the Buildings of the said Hospital, and adding more poor Persons to those already established therein, reciting, among other Things, that the Right Honourable Gilbert Earl of Shrewsbury, long since deceased, did, by his last Will and Testament (made about One hundred Years before the passing the said Act), appoint an Hospital to be founded at Sheffield in the County of York for the Maintenance of Twenty poor People, and to be called The Hospital of Gilbert Earl of Shrewsbury, and thereby ordered his Executors to endow the same with such Possessions and Revenues as they should think fit, not being under Two hundred Pounds per Annum; and also reciting, that the Most Noble Henry Duke of Norfolk deceased, thentofore Earl of Norwich, Grandfather to Thomas then Duke of Norfolk, and Great Grandson and Heir at Law to the said Earl of Shrews* bury, for performing the said Will, did, above Fifty Years before the [Private.2 q passing

11G. i. c. 33.

vesting in Trustees certain Estates in the Counties of York and Derby for the Support of the Hospital at Sheffield, founded pursuant to the Will of Gilbert Earl of Shrewsbury.

4° GEORGII IV. 28.

passing of the said Act, erect a Building or Hospital at Sheffield aforesaid, and did place therein Twenty poor Persons, Ten Men and Ten Women, and did appoint One of such Men to be Governor of the said Hospital, and in the Year One thousand six hundred and seventy-three made certain Statutes, Orders, and Constitutions for the Government of the said Hospital, and for the electing fit poor Persons out of the Town and Parish of Shffield aforesaid, if there to be found, and if none could there be found fit and qualified according to the said Constitutions, then out of any other Place or Parish where the said Earl of Norwich had any Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments descended to him from the said Gilbert Earl of Shrewsbury, the said poor Persons to be then after elected to be Successors of the said poor Men and poor Women in the said Hospital when or as they should die or be removed from their respective Places in the said Hospital, and appointed such Stipends to be paid to such Governor and poor Men and poor Women, and such Provisions of Coals, Clothes, and other Things to be made for them, and with such Rules and Orders for putting in, displacing, and governing the said poor Men and Women, and for dispensing with the said Orders and Regulations, as in the said Constitutions are expressed and appointed, and directed the Revenues of the said Hospital to be disposed of to the several Purposes before mentioned, and to such other Purposes as were in the said Orders and Constitutions mentioned, and gave such other Rules and Orders for maintaining and continuing the said Hospital as is therein expressed according to the said Will for ever; and further reciting, that the said Henry Duke of Norfolk being seised in Fee Simple of the Lands, Impropriations, and Tithes, and Hereditaments therein-after mentioned, situate and being respectively within the Counties of York and Derby, he the said Henry Duke of Norfolk by Indenture made betwixt him the said Henry Duke of Norfolk of the one Part, and Francis Jessop, Thomas Chappell, Cuthbert Browne, and William Spencer of the other Part, bearing Date the Twenty-third Day of November One thousand six hundred and eighty (but which Indenture is mentioned in the said Act to be then mislaid or lost), in performance of the Trust in him the said Duke touching the said Lands and Hereditaments, did grant, release, and convey the same to the said Francis Jessop, Thomas Chappell, Cuthbert Browne, and William Spencer, and their Heirs, in Trust that the said Trustees should by or out of the yearly Rents and Profits of the said Lands and Hereditaments maintain and keep the said House or Building, and the Gardens and Yards thereunto belonging, from Time to Time for ever, as Need or Occasion should be, with all needful and requisite Reparations, and should provide Gowns and other Provisions for the Governor and Governess, and all the Members and Officers of or belonging to the said Hospital for the Time being, for ever, according to the said Constitutions; it was by the said Act (amongst other things) enacted, that all the said Farms, Lands, Houses, Impropriations, Rectories, Tithes, Hereditaments, and Premises, should be and the same were thereby vested in William Jessop, Joseph Banks, William Levenz, William Green, John Batty, Wardall George West by, Robert Chappell, Samuel Stamford, and John Fenton, their Heirs and Assigns, to the Use and Behoof of them, their Heirs and Assigns, and that the said Trustees, their Heirs and Assigns, should apply certain Monies which had arisen out of the Rents and Profits of the said Hereditaments and Premises, and the yearly accruing Rents of the said Hereditaments and Premises, in the first Place

to the making all such Payments, Provisions, and Appointments to and for the then Members of the said Hospital, and their Successors, as were by the Constitution of the said Hospital appointed to and for them respectively, and should apply the Surplus to erect such additional Buildings as should be necessary for the Habitation of such poor People as should be added Members of the said Hospital; and also to maintain and keep the said House or Building called Sheffield Hospital, with the House and Chapel there, and the new intended Buildings there, and the Gardens and Yard thereunto belonging, from Time to Time for ever, with good and decent Order and Repairs; and after a Provision therein contained for maintaining an additional Number of poor Men and Women in the said Hospital, the Surplus of the said Monies, and also the Rents and Profits of the said Lands, was thereby directed to be applied to the Payment of the yearly Stipend of Thirteen Pounds to the Governor of the said Hospital, and also of the yearly Salary or Stipend of Fifteen Pounds to the said Governor as Receiver and Collector of the Rents and Revenues of the said Hospital, so long as he should from Time to Time be Receiver of the same; and it was thereby directed that the said Governor should also have the Benefit of letting such Seats and Pews in the said Chapel of the said Hospital as should not be made use of by the Members of the said Hospital; and it was thereby further enacted, that for ever thereafter the Governor of the said Hospital should be a Clergyman of the Church of England, and should be elected, appointed, and displaced for any Misfeazance or Neglect of his Duty, in the same Manner as the Governors of the said Hospital were elected and displaced, according to the said Constitutions, to the End that there might be Prayers according to the Church of England, and Two Sermons preached every Sunday in the said Chapel, and that the like Prayers might be read in the same Chapel Twice every Day as was then used throughout the Year; provided nevertheless, that such Governor, notwithstanding the said Constitutions, might be a married Man, or if a single Man might marry, and might lodge or dwell out of the said Hospital, so that he dwelt in the said Town of Sheffield, or in some Place not farther from the said Hospital than the said Town of Sheffield, and should be exempted from wearing a Scarlet Gown as directed by the said Constitutions, but instead thereof, and of Coals and Shirts annually allowed, such Governor should have the Price thereof in Money, (to wit), Five Pounds per Annum over and above all the Provisions aforesaid, as had been used and accustomed ever since the Governor of the said Hospital was a Clergyman, and also Five Pounds per Annum more, when the Revenues of the Hospital would conveniently bear the same, after the said additional poor should be added in lieu of what the former Collectors had as Charges in collecting the Tithes of Peniston in Kind when so collected; and it was thereby further enacted, that the Surplus of the Rents and Profits which should remain from Time to Time after making the said Provisions for the said Governor, and then present poor People, and the additional poor People to be added as aforesaid, and after making the said Repairs and Buildings, and after all the Trusts to which the same were thereby before directed to be applied should be satisfied, should be laid up in such Manner and for such Purposes as the said Constitutions directed the Surplus of the Monies belonging to the said Hospital to be laid up and disposed of: And whereas by Indentures of Lease and Release, bearing indentures of Date respectively the Tenth and Eleventh Days of June One thousand Lease and Reseven

stands in a low Situation, and it has not been deemed advisable to rebuild such of the Houses lately Parts thereof as were so destroyed as aforesaid 5 and it hath long been considered desirable that a new Hospital should be built in a more convenient Situation, and that no more Money should be expended in the Repairs of the present Hospital than was absolutely necessary to preserve the same in a habitable State; and it would require a considerable Sum of Money to rebuild the Houses so destroyed and not rebuilt for the Reasons herein-before mentioned, and to put the Buildings which at present constitute the Hospital into complete Repair, so as to insure that Accommodation and Comfort to the Inmates which it was the Object of the Founder to provide: And whereas, by the Provisions contained in the said Two first herein-before recited Acts, the Governor or Chaplain of the said Hospital is not bound to reside therein, and if he were so bound to reside there is not any Dwelling House attached to the said Hospital, or Apartment therein, suitable to his Residence, nor would the present Stipend allowed him by the said Constitutions and Acts form an adequate Provision for a resident Governor or Chaplain; and it would very much promote the Order and Welfare of the Establishment if the Governor and Chaplain were to be resident at the said Hospital; but in order to insure that desirable Object it is necessary that a suitable Habitation should be provided for him, and that the Patron and Visitor for the Time being of the said Hospital should have Power to direct a further annual Stipend to be paid to the said Governor or Chaplain out of the Revenues of the Hospital Estates: And whereas the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk, being desirous to promote the Objects of by the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk, his Heirs, Executors, or Administrators, to the Trustees of the said Hospital for the Time being of the Sum of One thousand Pounds, at the End of Six Calendar Months next after a certain Bill therein referred to, and meaning this present Act, should pass into a Law: And whereas the Provision contained in the said recited Act of the Tenth Year of His late Majesty, for Appointment of new Trustees of the said Estates belonging to the said Hospital, applies only to the Appointment of Trustees in lieu of those who may die, and in other respects is liable to practical Objections; and the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk is desirous that a more extensive and convenient Provision may be made relative to the Appointment of future Trustees of the said Hospital Estates: And whereas it would be for the Benefit of the said Hospital if the said Estates in the Township of Bright side in the Parish of Sheffield, and in Styrrup in the Parish of Harworth, so purchased out of the Funds belonging to the said Hospital, were annexed to the Estates of the said Hospital; and the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk is therefore desirous that the same should, so soon as may be after the passing of this Act, be conveyed by the said Lord Henry Molyneux Howard, Hugh Parker, and Vincent Henry Eyre, or the Survivors or Survivor of them, or his Heirs, so that the same may become legally vested in such Persons as shall for the Time being be the Trustees of the Estates of the said Hospital, upon such Trusts as the Estates with which the said Hospital is at present endowed are or shall for the Time being be subject to, under or by virtue of the Statutes, Ordinances, Deed of Endowment, and Acts of Parliament herein-before recited, or of this Act: And whereas inasmuch as the several Purposes which the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk is desirous of effecting cannot be effected without the Aid and Authority of Parliament; therefore Your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal Subject the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk, doth humbly beseech Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the Pieces or Parcels of Land, particularly mentioned and described in the First Schedule to this Act annexed, shall, from and immediately after the passing of this Act, be and the same are hereby appropriated as and for the Site of a New Hospital, and a Chapel and Governor’s House, with suitable Outbuildings, and for Yards, Gardens, a Paddock, and other Appendages thereto, according to the Plan herein-before referred to, or as near thereto as may be found convenient, in lieu of and in Exchange for the Piece of Ground and other Hereditaments described in the Second Schedule to this Act annexed.

II. And be it further enacted, That when and so soon as the said intended New Hospital and other Buildings shall have been built and completed, or the said present Hospital and the Buildings thereto belonging shall have been taken down, and the Materials thereof and all other Articles and Things whatsoever belonging thereto, shall have been removed (which ever shall first happen), the Site of the said present Hospital and Buildings, with the Yards and Gardens thereto belonging, and which Premises are particularly described in the Second Schedule to this Act annexed, shall thereupon and thenceforth be absolutely discharged

VI. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if the present Hospital shall be demolished or taken down as aforesaid, before so much at least of the said New Hospital shall be completed and ready for Occupation as shall be sufficient for the Reception of the poor Men and Women who at the Time of such Demolition shall belong to the Establishment, then and in such Case it shall be lawful for the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk, or other the Patron and Visitor for the Time being of the said Hospital, and he is hereby required, at the Expence of the Revenues of the said Charity, in the meantime until the said New Hospital shall be fit for Occupation, to provide proper and suitable Lodgings and Accommodations in or near the said Town of Sheffield for the said poor Men and Women, or such of them as the said new Buildings shall not from Time to Time be capable of accommodating.

VII. And be it further enacted, That when and so soon as the Messuage or Mansion intended to be provided for the Governor or Chaplain of the said Hospital shall be rendered fit for Habitation, the Governor or Chaplain for the Time being (other than and except the Reverend Downes the present Governor or Chaplain) shall be bound, and he is hereby required immediately thereupon, to enter into the Occupation of and reside in the same Messuage or Mansion; and that the Governor or Chaplain for the Time being of the said Hospital shall from Time to Time, and at all Times thereafter, make the same Messuage or Mansion the Place of his Abode; and that if, when the said Messuage or Mansion shall be rendered fit for Habitation as aforesaid, the Governor or Chaplain for the Time being of the said Hospital (other than and except the said present Governor or Chaplain) shall refuse or for the Space of Six Weeks thereafter neglect to enter into and reside in the same Messuage or Mansion, or if such Governor or Chaplain (except as aforesaid), having entered upon and resided in the said Messuage or Mansion, or any future

Governor or Chaplain of the said Hospital, shall wilfully absent himself therefrom for any Period exceeding the Space of One Month together, or to be accounted at several Times in any One Year, without the Consent in Writing of the Patron and Visitor for the Time being of the said Hospital, if adult, but if a Minor, then of the Guardian or Guardians of the the said Minor, first had and obtained, then and in any of such Cases the Governorship or Chaplaincy of the said Hospital shall become void, and it shall be lawful for the Patron and Visitor for the Time being of the said Hospital from Time to Time to appoint some other Person to be the Governor or Chaplain thereof.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That from and after the said intended Provision for New Hospital shall have been built, it shall be lawful for the Trustees for increasing the the Time being of the Estates of the said Hospital, and they are hereby directed, by or out of the Revenues of the said Hospital, to pay or allow to the Governor or Chaplain thereof for the Time being such yearly Sum or Sums, not being more than the clear yearly Sum of Two hundred Pounds, nor less than the clear yearly Sum of One hundred Pounds, as the said Bernard Edward Duke of Norfolk, or other the Patron and Visitor for the Time being of the said Hospital shall, by any Writing under his Hand, from Time to Time direct, and in case no such Direction shall be made, then the clear yearly Sum of One hundred Pounds as and for the Stipend of such Governor or Chaplain, by Four even Quarterly Payments on the usual Days for Payment of Rent in the Year, in lieu and full Satisfaction of all Payments and Allowances to which the present Governor or Chaplain is now entitled in respect of those Offices as hereinbefore is recited; and that in the Event of the Death or Resignation or Deprivation of any Governor or Chaplain of the said Hospital on any other Day than one of the Days whereon the Stipend hereby provided shall be payable, the then incurring Quarterly Payment of the same Stipend shall be apportioned between him or his Executors or Administrators, and his immediate Successor.

Cap. 29.

An Act for vesting Part of the Estates devised by the Will of Edward Mynors Esquire, situate in the Counties of Stafford and , in Trustees,

upon Trust to sell the same; and for laying out the Monies arising from such Sales in the Purchase of more convenient Estates, to be settled to the same Uses.

[10th July 1823.]
